content: Public Services in India are divided into 3 categories : All-India Services Central Services State Services All-India Services. IAS, IPS, IFS are the 3 All-India Services. Indian Forest Service was added in 1966. Centre in consultation with States makes rules for regulation of the services. Centre recruits & trains members to work in State cadres. They work in Centre on deputation for fixed tenure. Salary & service conditions of officers remain the same throughout the country. States bare the expenses. Ultimate control lies with Centre while immediate control is with States. Disciplinary action against them can only be taken by Centre. Central Services. Work under exclusive jurisdiction of Centre. Categorised into Group A, B, C & D services. Some Group A services include Indian Foreign Service / Indian Revenue Service / Indian Audit & Accounts Service etc. Most Group A Services have a corresponding Group B service as well. Group A and Group B services consist of Gazetted Officers while Group C services consist of clerical personnel, while Group D consist of Manual Personnel. State Services. Work under the exclusive jurisdiction of State Govts. Hold lower positions than members of All-India Services in States. Most State services consist of Administrative Service, Police Service, Forest Service, Judicial Service, etc. State Services also have categories of Group A, B, C, D or Class I, II, III, IV services. Group A and Group B services usually consist of Gazetted Officers while Group C & Group D services consist of non-gazetted employees. All-India Services Act of 1951 specifies reservation of a maximum 33.33 % of total All-India posts to be filled through promotion of officers from State services. Such promotions are made on recommendation of a selection committee presided over by a UPSC Chairman or member. Constitutional Provisions for Public Services. Article 308 to 314 in Part XIV contain provisions regarding public services. Article 308 clarifies that these do not apply to J&K. Recruitment & Service Conditions : Art 309 empowers Parliament & State Leg to regulate the recruitment & conditions of public servants under Centre & States, respectively. Parl or State Leg can impose ‘reasonable restrictions’ on the Fundamental Rights of Public Servants. Tenure of Office : Art 310 states that members of Central Services, Defence Services & All-India Services hold office during the pleasure of the Prez. Members of Civil services of a State hold office during pleasure of Governor. Prez or Gov may provide for a contract for payment of Compensation if the position of the public servant is abolished, or if public servant is dismissed for no personal fault or misconduct. Safeguards to Civil Servants : Art 311 States that Civil servant can’t be dismissed or removed by a subordinate authority. Civil Servant cannot be dismissed or removed without an inquiry & reasonable opportunity of being heard in respect of the charges. The above safeguards are not available to members of defence services. All-India Services : Article 312 makes following provisions in respect to All-India Services : Parl can create a new All-India Service if Rajya Sabha passes a resolution with 2/3rd majority supporting the necessity for the same. Parl can regulate the recruitment & conditions of service. 42nd Amd of 1976 made provision for All-India Judicial Service, where such a service could be created for posts equivalent to District Judge & above with a law of the Parliament, not requiring any further amendment.

Part XVll — Art 343 to 351 deals with Official Languages. Provisions are divided into : Language of Union. Regional Languages. Language of the Judiciary & text of laws. Special Directives. Language of the Union. Hindi written in Devanagari script if to be the official language of the Union. Form of numerals to remain international form & not Devanagari. English may be used for 15 years from commencement of Const (till 1965). Parl may allow use of English after 15 yrs for specified purposes. Prez must appoint Commission at end of 5 yrs & 10 yrs of commencement of Const to report on progressive use of Hindi & restrictions on English. Parl Committee to be made to look into recommendations of Commission. A Commission was appointed in 1955 but not in 1960. Parliament enacted the Official Language Act in 1963 to allow the use of English & Hindi for official purposes of Union & Parliament indefinitely. Regional Languages. Const doesn’t specify official languages of States, but makes following Provs : State Leg may adopt 1 or more lang used in the State or Hindi as Official Lang. Until then English continues to be Official Language. Choice of Lang not limited to the recognised lang under 8th Schedule. English is link lang between Union & States & among States. 2 or more States can agree to adopt Hindi as official lang to communicate between each other. President (on demand being made) may direct for official recognition of language if Prez is satisfied that a substantial proportion of the population in a State uses the language. Language of Judiciary & Text of laws. English is to be official language of all proceedings in SC & HCs, of all bills, Acts, Ordinances, orders, rules, regulations, bye-laws at Centre & State until the Parliament provides otherwise. Gov with consent of Prez, can allow proceedings in HC to be in another lang, but judgements, decrees, orders will be accompanied with English translations. State Leg can prescribe any lang for bills, Acts, Ordinances, orders, rules, regulations or bye-laws, but English translation must also be published. Hindi translation of Acts, Ordinances, orders, etc published under authority of Prez are authoritative texts. Every bill in Parl is accompanied with Hindi translations. Supreme Court only hears cases in English as use of other languages for proceedings will be unconstitutional. Protection of Linguistic Minorities. A person can submit a grievance to any officer or authority in any language used in the Union or the State even if the lang is not the official language. Every State & local authority should provide for facilities for instruction in mother-tongue at primary education to children belonging to linguistic minorities. The Prez may give necessary directions for this purpose. Prez must appoint a Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities to ensure implementation of Constitutional safeguards for Linguistic Minorities. Eight Schedule. At present there are 22 recognised languages in 8th Schedule : Assamese / Bengali / Bodo / Dogri / Gujarati / Hindi / Kannada / Kashmiri / Konkani / Maithili / Malayalam / Manipuri / Marathi / Nepali / Odia / Punjabi/ Sanskrit / Santhali / Sindhi / Tamil / Telugu / Urdu. Sindhi added through 21st Amd 1967 Konkani, Manipuri, Nepali through 71st Amd 1992 Bodo, Dongri, Maithili, Santhali through 92nd Amd 2003. Members of these languages are given representation in Official Language Commission. The forms, style & expression of these languages are to be used to enrich Hindi Language. Classical Language Status. In 2004, Govt of India decided to create a new category of language called “Classical Language”. Criteria for inclusion in this category includes, high antiquity of its early texts/recorded history over a period of 1,500 yrs to 2000 yrs, considered to valuable heritage by generations of speakers, and literary tradition that is original and not borrowed from another speech community. Currently there are 6 classic languages : Tamil (2004) / Sanskrit (2005) / Telugu (2008) / kannada (2008) / Malayalam (2013) / Odia (2014). Benefits : Classical Lang gets financial assistance to set up Centre of Excellence for study of that language. Also opens avenues for two major awards for scholars of eminence. UGC can be asked to create a certain number of professional chairs for classical languages in atleast Central Univs.

Introduction. Cooperative Societies are a voluntary group of people sharing common economic, social or welfare goals, coming together for mutual commercial, economic & developmental support. 97th Const Amd of 2011 gave Constitutional status & protection to cooperative societies. Made the right to form cooperatives a fundamental right (Article 19). Included a new Directive Principle of State Policy on promotion of Cooperatives (Article 43-B). It added a new Part IX-B entitled as “The Co-operative Societies” (Art 243-ZH TO 243-ZT. Constitutional Provisions. State Leg may make provision for Incorporation, regulation & winding-up of Cooperatives based on principles of voluntary formation, democratic control, member-economic participation, autonomous functioning. Strength : Board member strength decided by State Legislature (max 21). 1 seat reserved for SC or ST & 2 seats for women for Co-ops in which there are members from such categories. Term of Office is 5 years. There can be 2 co-opted members, without right to vote, from fields of banking, management, or other related fields(in addition to 21 directors) Additionally, Functional directors shall also be members of board. Election : Election to the board must take place before expiry of term of current board. Electoral powers to be vested in a body of choice by State Leg. Supersession & Suspension of Board : no board shall be superseded or kept under suspension for longer than 6 months. The grounds include : Persistent default / negligence of duties / committing acts against the cooperative or its members / elections not in accordance with the provisions of State Act. Supersession or suspension not possible for Co-ops with Govt shareholdings, loan, financial assistance, guarantee. Audit of Accounts : State Leg may make provisions for maintenance of accounts & audit of the same every year. Also lay down qualifications for auditors. A panel of auditors or auditing firms shall be selected by Govt, from which one will be appointed by General body of Co-op. Accounts of Co-ops will be audited within 6 months of close of financial year. Audit report of an apex cooperative society will be laid before Legislature. May also provide for convening of Gen Body within same period. Application of the Part lX-B : shall apply to multi-state Co-ops, where provisions regarding the Co-ops will be made by Centre. Shall also apply to UTs but Prez may exclude a part of the UT from the application of this Part lX-B.

Introduction. Administrative Reforms Commission recommended the setting up of Lokpal & Lokayuktas based on Ombudsman institutions in Scandinavian countries. Lokpal would deal with complaints against ministers & Secretaries at Centre & State levels. Lokayuktas (1 at Centre & 1 in each State) would deal with complaints against other specified high officials. ARC kept judiciary out of the purview of these authorities. Govt accepted the recommendations & tried several times to pass an Act. Finally Lokpal & Lokayuktas Act, 2013 was passed. First Lokpal was appointed in March 2019 with retired SC justice PC Ghose as its chairman. Features of the Act. Estb Lokpal at Centre, Lokayuktas in States. Jurisdiction of Lokpal includes PM, Ministers, MPs, Group A, B, C, D officers & other Central officials. Lokpal : consists of Chairperson & max 8 members (50% Judicial members). Chair & members will be selected through selection committee consisting PM, Speaker, LoP in LS, CJI or his nominee, eminent jurist nominated by Prez on recommendation of the other 4 members of committee. A Search Committee shall assist selection committee. 50% members of Search Committee will be SCs, STs, OBCs, Minorities & women. PM is under purview of Lokpal but with special process of handling complaints and certain exclusions on subject matters. Lokpal can refer complaints regarding Group A, B, C, D officers to CVC. In Group A, B officer case, CVC conducts preliminary enquiry & final decision is of Lokpal. In Group C, D officer case, CVC conducts preliminary enquiry & takes further decision subject to reporting & review by Lokpal. Lokpal will have power of superintendence over all authorities, including CBI, dealing with cases referred to them by Lokpal. High powered Committee, chaired by PM will select the Director of CBI. Provides for attachment & confiscation of property of civil servants acquired through corrupt means, even when prosecution is pending. States timeline for preliminary inquiry as 3 months, for investigation it’s 6 months, for trial it’s 1 year extendable by 1 year. Special courts to be set up. Max punishment under Prev of Corruption Act extended to 10 years. Institutions financed fully or partially by Govt are under purview of Lokpal, but not institutions which are aided by Govt only. Lokpal given power to grant sanction for prosecution of public servant. Contains provisions to strengthen CBI like, setting up of Directorate of Prosecution, maintenance of panel of advocates to deal with Lokpal cases, transfer of CBI officers involved in Lokpal cases with the consent of Lokpal, provisions of funds to CBI for investigating Lokpal cases. Entities with foreign donations of 10 lakh+ will be under purview of Lokpal. Mandates States to set up Lokayuktas within 365 days through an Act. Drawbacks of the Act : Lokpal cannot act suo moto. Provides for heavy punishment for false & frivolous complaints, which may deter complainants from lodging complaints. Anonymous complaints not allowed. Very non-transparent procedures of dealing with complaints against PM. Limitation period of 7 years to file complaints. Lokayuktas. Many states had set up Lokayuktas even before enactment of Lokpal & Lokayuktas Act 2013. First Lokayuktas established in Maharashtra. Structure of Lokayuktas differ from State to State. Some States have appointed Lokayuktas as well as Upalokayuktas. Some States have designated the authority as Lokpal. Features. Appointment : The Lokayuktas & Upalokayuktas are appointed by Governor. In most states, the Governor consults the CJ of HC & LoP in Legislative assembly. Qualifications : Judicial qualifications are prescribed for Lokayuktas in UP, Himachal Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Orissa, Karnataka & Assam. No specific qualifications prescribed in Bihar, Maharashtra & Rajasthan. Tenure : in most states tenure is 5 years or upto 65 years of age. Jurisdiction : no uniformity among States regarding jurisdiction. CM is included in purview of Lokayuktas in States like HP, AnP, MP, etc while not included in States like Maharashtra, UP, Bihar, etc. Ministers & higher civil Servants are included in the purview in most states. MLAs are in the purview in AnP, HP, Gujarat, UP, Assam. Local bodies, Corps, companies, societies are in purview in most States Investigations : in most states, Lokayuktas can initiate investigations suo moto except in UP, HP, Assam. Scope of Cases covered : Lokayuktas can consider the cases of grievances as well as allegations in Maharashtra, UP, Assam, Bihar Karnataka. However, in HP, AnP, Rajasthan, Gujarat, the job of Lokayuktas is confined to allegations only and not grievances. Other features : Lokayuktas present annual reports to the governor but Lokayuktas are responsible to the state legislature. Lokayuktas take help of State investigative agencies for inquires. Can call for relevant files and documents from State Govt depts. Recommendations of Lokayuktas are only advisory & not binding.

Introduction. Central Bureau of Investigation was set up in 1963. Functions as an attached office under Ministry of Personnel. The Special Police Establishment was merged with CBI & its powers derived from Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946, are excercised by CBI. Main investigation agency of Central Govt. Motto : Industry, Impartiality and Integrity. CBI has following divisions : Anti-corruption Division. Economic Offences Division. Special Crimes Division. Policy and international police cooperation division. Administration division. Directorate of Prosecution. Central Forensic Science Laboratory. Composition. Headed by Director, assisted by Special or Additional Director. Has numerous joint directors, Deputy inspector generals & other usual police ranks. Director has a security of tenure for 2 years. CVC has superintendence over cases under Prevention of Corruption Act. Centre shall appoint Director on the recommendation of committee consisting of PM, LoP in LS, CJI or SC judge nominated by him. Director of Prosecution is appointed by Centre on recommendation of CVC, holding Office for 2 years. Centre shall appoint officers above or of rank of SP on recommendation of a committee consisting of Central Vigilance Commissioner, Vigilance Commissioners, Secretary of Home Ministry, Secretary of Dept of Personnel. Functions. Investigating corruption cases of Central Govt employees. Earlier, prior approval of Centre was required to inquire into cases involving officers above the rank of Joint Secretary. This was ruled invalid by SC in 2014. Investigating cases of infringement of fiscal or economic laws, in consultation or at request of the concerned department. Investigating serious crimes having national or international significance. Coordinating activities of Anti-corruption agencies & police forces. Taking up on State govt request any matter of public importance. Maintaining crime statistics & disseminating criminal information. Acts as National Central Bureau of Interpol in India.

Introduction. Central Vigilance Commission was estb in 1964 by executive resolution. Later in 2003, Parliament enacted an Act making CVC a statutory body. CVC is conceived to be the apex vigilance institution, working independently, to act against complaints of corruption or misuse of Office. Consists of 1 Central Vigilance Commissioner & not more than 2 Vigilance Commissioners. Appointed by the Prez on recommendation of a committee consisting of PM, Union Home Minister & Leader of Opposition in Lok Sabha. Term & Removal. Hold office for a term of 4 years or until the age of 65. Not eligible for further employment under Centre or State. The Prez can remove CVC or VCs on following grounds : If judged as an insolvent. If has been convicted for an offence which (in opinion of Central Govt) involves a moral turpitude. If engages in any paid employment during term of Office. If in opinion of Prez, is unfit due to infirmity of body or mind. If he has acquired such financial or other interests as is likely to affect his official functions. Can be removed in grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity on the recommendation of the SC after it has conducted an inquiry. Salary & privileges of CVC is similar to UPSC Chairman, & of other commissioners is same as UPSC members. Cannot be reduced. Organisation. Secretariat : Consists of a Secretary, Joint Secretaries, Deputy Secretaries, Under Secretaries & office staff. Chief Technical Examiner’s Wing : consists of Chief Engineers. Functions : To conduct technical audits of Govt construction work. To investigate specific complaints regarding construction works. Assisting CBI on technical matters & evaluation of properties in Delhi. Advicing CVC in cases involving technical matters. Commissioners for Departmental Inquiries : function as inquiry officers to conduct oral inquiries in Departmental Proceedings initiated against public servants. Functions. To inquire into reference made by Centre alleging an employee of corruption. To inquire into complaints of corruption against All India Service Officers, Group ‘A’ officers of Central Govt, other Central Govt officials. Supervise & give directions to CBI in dealing with Corruption cases and review the progress regarding such cases. To review progress of applications for sanction of prosecution under Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988. To advice to Central Govt & its authorities on matters referred by them. To Supervise Vigilance administration in Central Ministries & its authorities. Centre is required to consult CVC in making rules for governing Vigilance & disciplinary matters relating to All-India Services & Central Services. CVC also partake in selection committees for Director & Deputy Director of Enforcement, officers in SP rank posts in CBI, Director of Prosecution in CBI. Receives info on suspicious trans under Prevention of Money Laundering Act Working of CVC. HQ is in Delhi. Vested with power to regulate its own procedure. Has all powers of a civil court, its proceedings are of a Judicial character. May call for reports from Centre or its authorities. CVC advices on course of action to Centre & its authorities regarding inquiries & advices appropriate action. If Centre or authority disagrees, a written record of reasoning for disagreement must be presented to CVC. CVC gives annual report to Prez who lays it before the Parliament. All Ministries & departments in Centre have a Chief Vigilance Officer who assists & advices the head of office on matters relating to Vigilance. Chief Vigilance Officer also forms a link between the ministry or department with the CVC & CBI. Whistle Blowers Act. The Whistle Blowers Bill was passed by Lok Sabha in 2011 but it could only be passed in Rajya Sabha in 2014. It became an Act on 9th May 2014. Features of this Act are as follows : Provides for mechanism for protecting the Whistle Blowers’ identity. It aims to encourage people to disclose info on corruption without fear. A person can make a disclosure to the CVC, at present. Act lays down punishment of upto 2 yrs or fine upto Rs 30,000 for false info. Disclosures are made in good faith, and person making the disclosure will sign a declaration stating that he believes the disclosed info to be true. Disclosures can be made in writing or email, along with evidence & materials. The person disclosing info must provide her identity for any action to be taken. No action is taken if identity of complainant is found to be false. Info on national security is out of preview of the Act. Act not applicable to J&K, armed forces, Special Protection Group.

Introduction. State Information Commissions are estb through official Gazette notification under provisions of RTI Act, 2005 by State Govts. Independent bodies looking into complaints & appeals against offices, financial inst, public sector undertakings, etc. under concerned State Govt. Consists of State Chief Information Commissioner & not more than 10 State Information Commissioners. Appointed by Governor on recommendation of a committee consisting of CM, Leader of Opp in LA, 1 State Cabinet Minister appointed by CM. Qualifications : Members should eminent persons with wide knowledge & experience. Should not be MPs or Members of Legislature in State or UTs. Should not hold an office of profit, connected with any political party, carrying on any business, pursuing any other profession. Tenure & Service Conditions. Hold office for 5 years or until the age of 65 years, whichever is earlier. Not eligible for reappointment. The Governor can remove the Commissioners for following reasons : If adjudged an Insolvent. If he has been convicted for an offence which involves a moral turpitude in the opinion of the Governor. If engages in any paid employment during term of Office. If in opinion of Gov, is unfit due to infirmity of body or mind. If he has acquired such financial or other interests as is likely to affect his official functions. Can be removed in grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity on the recommendation of the SC after it has conducted an inquiry. Salary & privileges of State Chief is equal to Election Commissioner, & of other commissioners is same as Chief Secretary. Cannot be reduced. Powers and Functions. Duty to receive & inquire into complaints from any person : Who hasn’t been able to submit request due to non-appointment of Public Information Officer. Who has been refused info requested. Who has received info on request within specified time. Who thinks fees charged are unreasonable. Who thinks info given is incomplete or misleading or false. Any other matter relating to obtaining info. Commission can suo moto order inquiry in any matter on reasonable grounds While inquiring, the Commission has following Civil court powers : Summoning or enforcing attendance of persons & compelling to give evidence under oath / requiring discovery & inspection of docs/ receiving evidence on affidavit / requisitioning any public record from court or office / summons for witnesses / any other prescribed power. Commission may examine authorities’ public records in the course of inquiry. Commission has power to ensure its decisions are implemented by public authorities, including : Providing access to info in a particular form. Directing authority to appoint Public Information officer. Publishing information or categories of information. Making necessary changes to practices relating to management, maintenance & destruction of records. Enhancing training provisions for officials on RTI. Seeking annual report from authority on compliance with RTI Act. Requiring authority to compensate applicant for any loss or detriment. Imposing penalties under this Act. Rejecting the application. Submits annual report to State Govt which lays it before the Legislature. Can recommend measures to public authority for conforming with RTI.

Independent body looking into complaints & appeals against offices, financial inst, public sector undertakings, etc. under Central Govt & UTs. Consists of Chief Information Commissioner & not more than 10 Information Commissioners. Appointed by Prez on recommendation of a committee consisting of PM, Leader of Opp in LS, & a Union Minister nominated by PM. Qualifications : Members should eminent persons with wide knowledge & experience. Should not be MPs or Members of Legislature in State or UTs. Should not hold an office of profit, connected with any political party, carrying on any business, pursuing any other profession. Tenure & Service Conditions. Can be removed in grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity on the recommendation of the SC after it has conducted an inquiry. Salary & privileges of CIC is same as Chief Election Commissioner, & of ICs is same as Election Commissioners. The same cannot be reduced during term. Powers and Functions. Duty to receive & inquire into complaints from any person : Who hasn’t been able to submit request due to non-appointment of Public Information Officer. Who has been refused info requested. Who has received info on request within specified time. Who thinks fees charged are unreasonable. Who thinks info given is incomplete or misleading or false. Any other matter relating to obtaining info. Commission can suo moto order inquiry in any matter on reasonable grounds While inquiring, the Commission has following Civil court powers : Summoning or enforcing attendance of persons & compelling to give evidence under oath / requiring discovery & inspection of docs/ receiving evidence on affidavit / requisitioning any public record from court or office / summons for witnesses / any other prescribed power. Commission may examine authorities’ public records in the course of inquiry. Commission has power to ensure its decisions are implemented by public authorities, including : Providing access to info in a particular form. Directing authority to appoint Public Information officer. Publishing information or categories of information. Making necessary changes to practices relating to management, maintenance & destruction of records. Enhancing training provisions for officials on RTI. Seeking annual report from authority on compliance with RTI Act. Requiring authority to compensate applicant for any loss or detriment. Imposing penalties under this Act. Rejecting the application. Commission submits annual report to Centre which lays it before the Parl. Can recommend measures to public authority for conforming with RTI.

Introduction. Protection of Human Rights Act of 1993 also provides for creation of State Human Rights Commission at the State level. The Act also provide for estb of Human Rights Courts in every district, to be set up by State Govt with concurrence of CJ of HC. State Human Rights Commission can inquire into violation of HR in relation to subjects in State List & Concurrent List. It cannot inquire into cases being inquired into by NHRC or any other Statutory Commission. Its recommendations are not binding, but it should be informed on action taken within 1 month. It submits reports to the State Govt which are then laid before Legislature along with memorandum of action, & reasons for non-acceptance of recommendations. Composition of the Commission. Consists of 1 Chairperson & 2 members. Chairperson should be retired CJ of HC. 1 Member should be serving or retired HC judges or District Judge (with minimum 7 yrs of experience as District Judge). 1 Member should be eminent person in the field of Human Rights. Chairperson & members appointed by the Governor on recommendation of a committee consisting of – CM, Speaker of LA, State Home Minister, Leader of Opposition in LA. If State has Leg Council, then Chairman & LOP in Council are also members. Sitting judge can be appointed only after consultation with CJ of HC. Tenure & Removal. Chairman & members hold office for a term of 5 years or until the age of 70 years, which ever is earlier. Chairman & members are not eligible for further employment under Central or State Govt. Chairman or members can only be removed by Prez on following grounds : If adjudged an Insolvent. If engages in any other paid employment during term of Office. If unfit to continue due to infirmity of mind or body. If declared of unsound mind by a competent court. If convicted or sentenced for imprisonment for an offence. Can be removed in Grounds of proven misbehaviour or incapacity if the SC, after an inquiry, recommends so to the President. Salary & allowances are fixed by State Govt but cannot be reduced after appointment. Functions of the Commission. To inquire into any violation of Human Rights or negligence in prevention of such violation by a public servant, either suo moto or on petition submitted to it or on the orders of a court. To intervene in a pending matter in a court regarding Human Rts violation. To visit jails, detention places to study living conditions of inmates. To review Const & other safeguards & ensure better implementation. Review & Recommend measures agn factors like terrorism which inhibit HR. To study treaties & International instruments on human Rts & recommend measures for their implementation. To undertake & promote research in the field of Human Rights. To spread Human rights literacy & promote safeguards for protection of Rts. To encourage NGOs working in the field of Human Rights. To take such other functions that it may consider necessary for promotion of human rights. Working of the Commission. Vested with power to regulate its own procedure. Has all powers of civil court & proceedings are of a Judicial character. May call for reports from State Govt or subordinate authority. Has own investigation staff. Has powers to utilise services of any officer or investigation agency in the Centre or State. Only empowered to look into any matter within 1 year of its occurrence. Commison may take following steps during or after Inquiry : May recommend State govt or concerned authority to — pay compensation to the victims / initiate proceedings for prosecution or other actions of guilty public servant / grant immediate interim relief to the victim. It may approach the SC or State HC for necessary directions, orders or writs.

Introduction. National Human Rights Commission is a statutory body. Estb in 1993 through Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993. Its a watchdog for Human rights in the country – Rights relating to life, liberty, equality and dignity of individuals. Its recommendations are not binding, but it should be informed on action taken within 1 month. It submits reports to the Central Govt or concerned State Govt which are then laid before Legislature along with memorandum of action, & reasons for non-acceptance of recommendations. Composition of the Commission. Consists 1 Chairman & 4 other members. Chairman must be retired CJI. Members should be retired or serving SC judges, or retired or serving CJs of HC. 2 members should be eminent persons in the field of Human Rights. Commission also has 4 ex-officio members – Chairmen of National Commission for Minorities/ SCs / STs / Women. Chairman & members are appointed by Prez on recommendation of a 6 member committee consisting of : PM, Speaker, Deputy Chairman of RS, Leaders of Opposition in both Houses, Union Home Minister. Sitting Judges of SC or CJ of HC can be appointed as members only in consultation with CJI. Tenure & Removal. Chairman & members hold office for a term of 5 years or until the age of 70 years, which ever is earlier. Chairman & members are not eligible for further employment under Central or State Govt. Prez can remove Chairman or members on following grounds : If adjudged an Insolvent. If engages in any other paid employment during term of Office. If unfit to continue due to infirmity of mind or body. If declared of unsound mind by a competent court. If convicted or sentenced for imprisonment for an offence. Can be removed in Grounds of proven misbehaviour or incapacity if the SC, after an inquiry, recommends so to the President. Salary & allowances are fixed by Centre but cannot be reduced after appointment. Functions of the Commission. To inquire into any violation of Human Rights or negligence in prevention of such violation by a public servant, either suo moto or on petition submitted to it or on the orders of a court. To intervene in a pending matter in a court regarding Human Rts violation. To visit jails, detention places to study living conditions of inmates. To review Const & other safeguards & ensure better implementation. Review & Recommend measures agn factors like terrorism which inhibit HR. To study treaties & International instruments on human Rts & recommend measures for their implementation. To undertake & promote research in the field of Human Rights. To spread Human rights literacy & promote safeguards for protection of Rts. To encourage NGOs working in the field of Human Rights. To take such other functions that it may consider necessary for promotion of human rights. Working of the Commission. HQ is in Delhi. Can also establish offices at other places. Vested with power to regulate its own procedure. Has all powers of civil court & proceedings are of a Judicial character. May call for reports from Centre or State Govt or authority. Has own investigation staff. Has powers to utilise services of any officer or investigation agency in the Centre or State. Only empowered to look into any matter within 1 year of its occurrence. Commison may take following steps during or after Inquiry : May recommend concerned govt or authority to — pay compensation to the victims / initiate proceedings for prosecution or other actions of guilty public servant / grant immediate interim relief to the victim. It may approach the SC or concerned HC for necessary directions, orders or writs.

Introduction. National Institute for Transforming India was estb on January 1, 2015. Created through an executive resolution. Replaced Planning Commission. It is policy ‘Think Tank’ for the Govt. Provides directional and policy inputs to Govt. Looks to enhance cooperation and collaboration between Centre and States. Composition. Chairperson : The Prime Minister of India. Governing Council : CMs of all States & UTs, Lt. Govs of UTs. Regional Councils : formed for a specified tenure to address specific issues in any region. Chaired by PM, comprising of CMs and LGs of States & UTs in the region. Special Invitees : experts and specialists nominated by PM. Full-Time Organisational Framework : Consists of Chairperson and : Vice-Chairperson appointed by PM (enjoys rank of Cabinet Minister). Members enjoying rank of Minister of State. Part-time members : Max 2 from leading universities, research organisations, other institutes in ex-officio capacity. Ex-officio members : Max of 4 nominated from Union CoM. CEO appointed by PM for fixed tenure in rank of Sec to Govt of India. Secretariat as deemed necessary. Specialised Wings. Research Wing : develops in-house expertise in various sectors as a think tank of experts, scholars and specialists. Consultancy Wing : provides a market place from which Govt in Centre and States can choose experts and specialists to advise on various matters. Team India Wing : comprises of representatives of every State and serves as a common platform to voice opinions, enhance communications and improve coordination. Objectives. To make a ‘National agenda’ with the inputs of all States, UTs and Centre. To foster cooperative federalism. To consider the needs of smaller units like villages and make plans starting from there and only them moving upwards. To ensure equal development of all through special attention to certain sections of the society like to have lower benefits than the rest of India. To design strategic and long-term policy with innovative ideas. To provide expert advice to States and Centre through pooling of experts. To provide a platform for resolution of inter-sectoral issues. To continue research on good governance. To monitor and evaluate implementation of plans and policies. To focus on technology driven policy implementation. To undertake other activities to implement the national development agenda. Other Bodies. National Institute of Labour Economics Research & Development (former Institute of Applied Manpower Research) is subordinate to the NITI Aayog. Main objective is to advance knowledge of human resources and human capital development. It also monitors and evaluates public policies. National Development Council consists of PM, Union Cabinet Ministers, CMs & Administrators, Members of the NITI Aayog. Originally functioned to prescribe guidelines to the Planning Commission for making 5 year plans. It also considered the National Plan made by the commission and reviewed its working once implemented. It was listed as an advisory body to the Planning Commission. The last meeting took place in 2012 and the Council has remained defunct since then.

Introduction. Article 165 provides for the advocate general of the States. Highest law officer in the State. Advocate General is appointed by the Governor. Must be qualified to be appointed as a judge of a High Court. The term of Office, procedure and grounds for removal have not been specified in the Constitution. The Adv General conventionally resigns along with the CoM. Duties and Functions. To give advice to the Govt of the State on legal matters referred to by the Governor. To perform other legal duties assigned by Governor. To discharge functions conferred by the Constitution or any other law. The Advocate General, in performance of official duties, is entitled to appear before any court in the State. Has right to speak and take part in proceedings of both Houses of the State Legislature, except to vote. Can be part of any House Committee but without the right to vote. Enjoys all privileges and immunities available to a member of the State Legislature.

Introduction. Article 76 provides for the office of the Attorney General of India. Highest law office in the country. Appointed by Prez. Must be a person qualified to be a judge of Supreme Court. Term of Office not fixed by Constitution. Constitution does not provide for removal process. AG serves at the pleasure of the President, and resigns along with the Council of Ministers on whose recommendation the appointment was made. President determines the renumerations of the AG. Not debarred from private legal practice. Duties & Functions. To give legal advice to Govt on matters referred to by Prez. To perform such other legal duties assigned by the Prez. To discharge functions conferred on him by Constitution or any law. The Prez has assigned following duties to AG : To represent the Govt of India in all cases in the Supreme Court. To represent the Govt of India in any reference made by Prez to SC under Art 143. To represent the Govt of India in any HC if so required by the Govt. Rights and Limitations. AG has right of audience in all courts in the Territory of India to perform her official duties. Has Right to speak and take part in proceedings of both Houses of Parliament and of joint sittings, but without the right to vote. Can be appointed as a member of any Parliamentary Committee but without voting rights. Enjoys all privileges and immunities available to a member of Parliament. Following limitations are placed on AG : Should not advise or hold a brief against the Govt of India. Should not advise or hold a brief in cases where he is representing the Govt of India. Should not defend accused persons in criminal cases without Govt approval. Should not be a director in a company or Corp without Govt approval. Solicitor General of India. In addition to AG there are other law officers of Govt of India. There are Solicitor General of India and Additional Solicitor General of India. They assist the AG in fulfilling the duties of the office. These offices are not created by the Constitution.

Introduction. Article 148 provides for independent Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India. Head of the Indian Audit and Accounts Department. Guardian of Public purse at both Centre and State levels. Duties include upholding Constitutional and Parliamentary laws regarding financial administration. Appointed by Prez to hold office for 6 years or upto 65 years of age. Can be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court judge. In 1976, CAG was relieved of duties of compilation and maintenance of accounts of Central Govt. Independence. Constitution makes several provisions to ensure independence of CAG : Provided with security of tenure. Can only be removed through the same process for removing a Supreme Court judge. Not eligible for any other Office at Centre or State after retirement. Salary and allowances fixed by Parliament. Salary and allowances, including pension, cannot be reduced after appointment. Service conditions of employees in Indian Audit and Accounts Department & administrative powers of CAG are prescribed by Prez in consultation with CAG. All expenses of the office of CAG is charged upon Consolidated Fund of India. Duties and Powers. Art 149 authorises Parliament to prescribe powers & Duties of CAG. Parl enacted CAG’s (Duties, Powers & Conditions of Service) Act, 1971 : Audits accounts related to expenditure from Consolidated Fund, Contingency Fund and Public Accounts at both Centre and States. Audits all financial records of departments of Central & State Govts. Audits receipts & expenditure of all Centrally or State financed bodies, Govt companies, other corporations and bodies when required by law. Audits transactions related to debt, deposits, advances, etc. Audits accounts of any other authority when requested by Prez or Gov. Art 150 : advises on the form in which accounts of Centre & States are kept. Art 151 : Submits reports relating to Centre to Prez and of States to Gov. Art 279 : ascertains & certifies net proceeds (tax minus cost of collection) of tax or duty. Acts as a guide and advisor to Public Accounts Committee of Parliament. CAG and Corporations. Role of CAG in auditing of public corporations is limited : Some corporations are audited totally by CAG including Damodar Valley Corp, ONGC, Air India, etc. Some other Corps are audited by private professional auditors appointed by Centre in consultation with CAG. If necessary, CAG can conduct Supplementary audits. Eg include Central Warehousing Corp, Industrial Finance Corp, etc. Some other Corps are totally subjected to private audit and they submit their reports directly to the Parliament, eg LIC, RBI, SBI, FCI, etc. Role of CAG in auditing Govt Companies is also limited, as they are audited by private professional auditors appointed by Centre in consultation with CAG.

Constitutional Provisions. Originally no provision mentioned in Constitution for Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities. States Reorganisation Commission made recommendation in this regard. 7th Const Amd inserted Article 350B in Part-XVII : Provided for Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities, appointed by Prez. It would be duty of the Officer to investigate matters relating to Constitutional safeguards for Linguistic Minorities. Officer would also submit reports to the Prez on the Prez’s directions. Prez shall put such reports in front of Parliament and states concerned. Constitution doesn’t specify the qualifications, tenure, salary or service conditions for the Officer. Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities. Article 350B estb the office of the Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities designated as Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities. Headquartered at Prayagraj with 3 regional offices at Belgaum, Chennai & Kolkata headed by Assistant Commissioner. Commissioner at HQ is assisted by Deputy Commissioner and Assistant Commissioner. The Commissioner falls under the Ministry of Minority Affairs. Functions & Objectives. To investigate all matters related to safeguards provided to linguistic minorities. To submit reports to Prez on status of implementation of Constitutional and other safeguards provided for Linguistic Minorities. To monitor implementation of safeguards through, questionnaires, visits, conferences, seminars, meetings, review mechanisms, etc. Objectives : To provide equal opportunities to linguistic minorities for their inclusive development. To spread awareness amongst linguistic minorities regarding safeguards. To ensure effective implementation of safeguards. To take up matters pertaining to grievances arising out of violation or non-implementation of safeguards.

Introduction. National Commission for STs is directly established by Article 338-A. The National Commission for SCs and STs was established in 1990 through 65th Amendment Act. The 89th Constitutional Amendment added an Article 338-A in 2003, creating a separate National Commission for STs which was established in 2004. It consists of 1 Chairperson, 1 Vice-Chairperson & 3 other members appointed by the President of India. Their conditions of office and tenure is determined by the President. Functions of the Commission. To investigate & monitor the Constitutional & other safeguards provided for STs and whether they are effective. To inquire into complaints of violation of rights of STs. To participate and advice in the planning for socio-economic development of STs. To present reports annually or earlier to the President on above matters. To recommend measures to be taken by the Govts to further Safeguard the rights of STs across the nation. To discharge such other functions regarding welfare and development of STs as the President may specify : Measures to be taken for conferring ownership rights on minor forest produce/ safeguarding rights of Tribes over mineral resources, etc./ to provide viable livelihood/ to ensure full implementation of provisions of PESA Act of 1996. Powers of the Commission. Commission is vested with power to regulate its own procedure. The commission while investigating any matter or inquiring into any complaint will have powers equivalent to a civil court in following respects : Summoning & enforcing attendance of any person under oath. Requiring discovery & production of any document. Receiving evidence in affidavits. Requisitioning any public record from any court. Issuing summons for examination of witnesses & documents. Any other matter which the President may determine. Central & State Govt are required to consult the commission on all major policy matters affecting STs.

Introduction. National Commission for Scheduled Castes is a Constitutional body as it is established by Article 338. Originally, Art 338 provided for a Special Officer for SCs & STs who was designated as a Commissioner. In 1978, Govt through a resolution estb a multi-member commission for SCs & STs. In 1987, the Govt passed a resolution to modify this Commission and renamed it as National Commission for SCs and STs. The 65th Const Amd 1990 replaced the Special Officer for SCs & STs with the National Commission for SCs and STs. The 89th Amd 2003, bifurcated the Commission into separate National Commission for SCs (Art 338) & National Commission for STs (338-A). National Commission for SCs came into existence in 2004. It has a Chairperson, a Vice-Chairperson & 3 other members. They are appointed by President who also decides their Condition of service & tenure. Functions of the Commission. To investigate & monitor all matters relating to Constitutional & other Safeguards for the SCs. To inquire into specific complaints with respect to violation of rights & safeguards of the SCs. To participate & advice on planning process of socio-economic development of the SCs & to evaluate their development at the Centre or States. To present to the Prez reports annually or earlier, upon the working of the safeguards. To make recommendations to the Union or a state as to the measures to be taken in order to ensure effective implementation of safeguards. To discharge such other functions in relation to the protection & welfare of SCs as the Prez may specify. Powers of the Commission. Commission is vested with power to regulate its own procedure. The commission while investigating any matter or inquiring into any complaint will have powers equivalent to a civil court in following respects : Summoning & enforcing attendance of any person under oath. Requiring discovery & production of any document. Receiving evidence in affidavits. Requisitioning any public record from any court. Issuing summons for examination of witnesses & documents. Any other matter which the President may determine. Central & State Govt are required to consult the commission on all major policy matters affecting SCs. Commission is also required to discharge similar functions for OBCs & Anglo-Indian Community as it does for SCs.

Composition. Art 280 provides for Finance Commission as a Quasi-judicial body. It is constituted by Prez every 5th year or even earlier as required. Consists of a Chairman & other members who hold office for such period as specified by Prez. They are eligible for reappointment. Constitution authorises Parliament to determine qualifications for office. Accordingly, Chairman should be a person having experience in public affairs while 4 other members should be selected from following : A judge of HC or a judge qualified to be one. A person having specialised knowledge of finance & accounts. A person having wide experience in financial matters & in administration A person having special knowledge of economics. Functions. Finance Commission is required to make recommendations to President on following matters : Distribution of net proceeds of taxes to be shared by Centre & States & the allocation of shares between states. Principles that should govern Grants-in-Aid to the States by Centre. Measures required to augment the Consolidated Fund of States to supplement resources of Panchayats & Municipalities on the basis of recommendations by State Finance Commission. On other matters referred to by the President. Commission submits its report to the President, who lays it before the Parliament with a memorandum as to the actions taken so far. Advisory Role. Recommendations made by the commission are only of an advisory nature. It is upto Union Govt to accept the recommendation to share revenue from taxes with States. However, since the Finance Commission is a Constitutional body of Quasi-judicial nature, its recommendations should not be turned down by the Govt unless there are very compelling reasons. Constitution of India envisages the Finance Commission of playing a very important role in ensuring the fiscal balance between Centre & States & among the States themselves. However, due to the establishment of the Planning Commission, now replaced by the NITI Aayog, the role of Finance Commission has been diminished to a certain degree with many planning functions overlapping between the two organisations.

State Public Service Commissions in the States are parallel to the Union Public Service Commission at the Centre. The same set of Articles 315 to 323 in Part XIV deal with the SPSC. Composition & Removal. Consists of a Chairman & other members appointed by the Governor. Strength of the commission is left to the discretion of the Governor. Half of the members of the commission must have served in the Central or State Govt for 10 years. Governor determines the conditions of service of the chairman & members. Chairman & Members hold office for a period of 6 years or till the age of 62 whichever is earlier. Acting Chairman can be appointed when chair falls vacant or is incapable. Chairman and members can only be removed by the President in the same manner as the Chairman and members of the UPSC. Independence & Functions. Constitution has made following provisions to Safeguard SPSC : Can only be removed by Prez on grounds mentioned in Const. Conditions of Office cannot varied to disadvantage. Entire expense of SPSC is charged on Consolidated Fund of State. Chairman after retirement is eligible to join any other public services commission or UPSC but no other employment. Members are eligible to Join other PSCs or UPSC but no other employment. Chairman or members are not eligible for a second term in office. SPSC performs all functions in State that UPSC does at Centre like conducting exams for appointment to State services. Giving advice on various matters related to personnel management including disciplinary action promotion, transfer, etc. SC ruled that consultation with SPSC is not mandatory for Govt. Joint State Public Service Commission. Constitution makes a provision for Joint State Public Service Commissions for 2 or more States. JSPSCs can be created through Acts of Parliament on the request of State Legislatures. Thus they are statutory & not Constitutional bodies. Chairman & members of JSPSC are appointed by Prez. They hold office for a term of 6 years or until the age of 62,whichever is earlier. Tehy can be suspended or removed by President. Strength of JSPSC and the service conditions of the members is decided by the President.

UPSC is a Central Recruiting Agency in India. It is an independent Constitutional body. Art 315 to 323 in Part XIV contain provisions regarding the UPSC. Composition. UPSC consists of a Chairman & other members. No specific provision as to the strength of the UPSC. No specific qualifications have been provided for membership other than half of the members should have held office under Govt of India or State for atleast 10 years. Prez is empowered to determine the conditions of service of the members. Chairman & members hold office for a term of 6 years or until they achieve 65 years of age, whichever is earlier. Prez can appoint any member as Acting chairman when the office of the chairman falls vacant or when chairman is unable to perform her duties due to absence or other reasons. Acting chairman continues until chairman resumes office or new chairman take office. Removal. President can remove chairman or member under following circumstances : If adjudged as an insolvent. If engages in any paid employment during term of Office. If, in Prez’s opinion, is unfit to continue due to infirmity of mind or body. Prez can remove Chairman or member for misbehaviour only after an enquiry & advice by the SC. SC’s advice in this case is binding. The member can be suspended by Prez during the time of enquiry. Independence. Following provisions are made to maintain independence of UPSC : Chairman or member can only be removed on grounds mentioned in Const. Conditions of service cannot be varied to disadvantage during term of Office. Expenses of UPSC are charged ON Consolidated Fund of India. Chairman of UPSC is not eligible for Govt employment in Centre or states. Member is eligible for Chairman of UPSC or SPSC but not other employment. Chairman or member is not eligible for a second term in office. Functions. To conduct exams for appointments to All-India Services, Central Services, public services to Centrally Administered Territories. To assist States, on request, for schemes of joint recruitment into services. Serves all or any need of a State on request of Gov & consent of Prez. It is Consulted on all matters of appointments regarding methods, principles for appointment & suitability of candidates. It is also Consulted for promotions or transfer from one service to another. All matters relating to discipline of civil Servants under the Govt of India. Any other matter relating to personnel management. SC ruled that the provision to consult UPSC is not mandatory. Prez can exclude posts, services, & matters from the purview of the UPSC.

Election Commission is a permanent & independent body created by the Constitution to ensure free & fair elections. Art 324 declares the power of superintendence of elections to Parliament, State Legislatures, Office of Prez & VP shall be vested in EC. Election Commission is not concerned with election to Panchayats and other local bodies. Composition. Art 324 makes following provisions with regard to EC’s composition : EC shall have a Chief Election Commissioner & other election commissioners as president may fix from time to time. Appointments of CEC & ECs shall be made by Prez. CEC shall act as chairman of the Commission. Prez may also appoint regional commissioners in consultation with CEC. Condition of service & tenure of commissioners will be decided by Prez. Presently the EC consists of 1 Chief Election Commissioner & 2 other Election Commissioners. CEC & other ECs have equal powers & receive equal salary & allowances to that of a judge of Supreme Court. Matters are decided by the majority. They hold office for a term of 6 years or until age of 65 whichever is earlier. Election Commission is assisted by Deputy Election Commissioner, drawn for civil Servants, appointed by the commission with tenure system. At the State level, the Commission is assisted by the Chief Election Officer who is appointed by CEC in consultation with the State Govt. Below this at the District level, the Collector acts as the district returning officer. The district collector appoints a returning officer for every constituency within the district & Presiding officers for every polling booth in the constituency. Independence. Art 324 has made following provisions to ensure EC’s independence : The CEC can only be removed in the same manner & grounds as an SC judge. Service conditions of CEC can’t be varied to her disadvantage. Other commissioners cannot be removed except on recommendation of CEC. Flaws in the safeguards : Constitution hasn’t prescribed any qualifications for members of EC. Constitution has not debarred the commissioners from hold a Govt Appointment after retirement. Powers & Functions. Powers & Functions of EC are as follows : To determine Territorial areas of constituencies on the basis of Delimitation Commission Act of Parliament. To prepare & periodically revise electoral rolls & to register eligible voters. To notify Schedule of elections & scrutinise nomination papers. To grant recognition to political parties & allot symbols and act as a Court to resolve disputes regarding the same. To appoint officers to enquire into electoral arrangements. To determine the electoral code of conduct. To prepare a roster for airing publicity ads of political parties in elections. advise Prez on disqualification of MPs & to cancel polls in case of rigging, etc. To supervise election machinery to ensure free & fair elections. To advise Prez on whether elections can be held in a state under Prez’s rule. Register pol. parties for elections & grant status of national or state parties.

Introduction. Article 244 in Part X envisages a special system of administration for certain areas designated as scheduled & Tribal areas. Fifth Schedule deals with admin and control of Scheduled areas and Scheduled Tribes in all States except Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura & Mizoram. Sixth Schedule deals with admin & control of Tribal Areas in the North Eastern States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura & Mizoram. Administration of Scheduled Areas. Various features of Admin contained in Fifth Schedule are : Prez is empowered to declare or undeclare an area as scheduled, increase or decrease or change its boundary or make any fresh order in this regard. The exec power of States extend to these areas, but Gov has special responsibility for these areas. Gov has to submit reports to Prez & Centre can give directions to State regarding admin of these areas. Each state having scheduled areas must establish a Tribes Advisory Council to advice on the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes. Should consist 20 members, 3/4th should be ST members of Leg Assembly. Similar Council can be estb in states not having scheduled areas but STs only if Prez directs so. Gov can direct that any Central or State law does not apply to a Scheduled area or applies with modifications. Gov with consent of Prez & with advice of Tribes Advisory Council can make regulations regarding transfer of land, allotment of land, money-lending & to repeal or amend a central or state law. Administration of Tribal Areas. Various features of administration in Sixth Schedule are : Tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura & Mizoram have been constituted as autonomous districts. States still have exec authority over such areas. Gov is empowered to organise & reorganise these districts. Gov can divide a district into several autonomous regions of there are different Tribes there. Each district has a District Council having 30 members (4 nominated by Gov, 26 elected). Elected members hold office for 5 yrs. Nominated members hold office in pleasure of Gov. Each autonomous region has a Regional Council. District & Regional councils can make laws on certain matters like land, forests, village admin, inheritance, marriage, etc with consent of Gov. Councils can constitute village councils or courts for trial of Tribal disputes. Councils can levy certain taxes and collect land revenue. Central & State Laws don’t apply to these districts or apply with modification. Gov can appoint commission to examine/ report on matters of such districts.

Introduction. Article 1 recognises Union Territories as a part of Territory of India. UTs function under the direct control of the Central Govt. Also known as Centrally Administered Territories. During British Rule certain areas were constituted as scheduled areas, which were later known as ‘chief commissioners Provinces’. After Independence, they were placed in Part ‘C’ & Part ‘D’ States. In 1956, through 7th Const Amd & State Reorganisation Act, they were constituted as Union Territories. Some of these UTs were later given statehood. There are seven UTs as of now : Andaman and Nicobar Islands / Delhi / Lakshadweep —— 1956 Dadra and Nagar Haveli—1961 / Daman and Diu—1962 / Puducherry—1962 / Chandigarh — 1966. Administration of Union Territories. Art 239 to 241 in Part VIII of the Constitution deals with UTs. No uniformity in administrative system of UTs. Administered by Prez through an administrator appointed by the Prez. The administrator is only an agent of the President & not the Head of State. Prez specifies the designation as Lieutenant Governor or Chief Commissioner or Administrator. Gov of a State can also be appointed as admin of an adjoining UT. Delhi & Puducherry has a Leg Assembly & CoM. Parl can make laws on all 3 lists in all UTs including Delhi & Puducherry. Puducherry can make laws on all State & Concurrent subjects. Prez can also make regulations here when Legislature is not in session. Parl can estb a high court for a UT. Delhi is only UT with own HC (1966). Bombay HC— D&N Haveli, Daman & Diu / Calcutta HC – A&N Isld / Punjab & Haryana HC – Chandigarh/ Kerela HC- Lakshadweep/Madras – Puducherry. Special Provisions for Delhi. 69th Const Amd of 1991 gave special status to Delhi, redesignating it as the National Capital Territory of Delhi. It created the Legislative assembly & Council of Ministers. Strength of Leg Assembly is fixed at 70 members. It can make laws on all matters of State & Concurrent list except Public Order, Police & land. Parl can also make laws on matters of all lists and these laws prevail. Strength of CoM is fixed at 10% of LA that is 1 CM & 6 Ministers. CM is appointed by President (not LG). CoM advises the LG. In case of difference of opinion, LG can refer to Prez. When Leg Assembly is not in session, LG can make Ordinances with the prior permission of Prez. Such Ordinances must be approved by LA within 6 months of reassembly. In case of break down of Constitution Machinery, President can impose her rule over Delhi either on the the report of the LG or otherwise. Advisory Committees of UTs. Ministry of Home Affairs is nodal ministry for all matters of UTs. All 5 UTs without Legislatures have the forum of Home Minister’s Advisory Committee (HMAC) / Administrator’s Advisory Committee (AAC). HMAC is chaired by Home Minister / AAC is chaired by Administrator of concerned UT. Local Members of Parliament, elected members from local bodies are members of these committees. Discusses General issues relating to development of the Union Territories.

Introduction. Municipalities are a form ‘Urban Local Government’. In 1687-88, first Municipal Corporation was set up at Madras. In 1726, Municipal Corporations were set up in Bombay & Calcutta. Lord Ripon’s resolution of 1882 was hailed as ‘Magna Carta’ of local self-government. He is known as Father of Local Self-government. Under Provincial Autonomy scheme introduced by Govt of India Act 1935, local self Govt was declared a Provincial subject. Rajiv Gandhi Govt & VP Singh Govt introduced Constitutional Amendment Acts in the form of Nagarpalika Bill but were unable to make it an Act. Finally, P V Narasimha Rao Govt introduced and passed the 74th Amd Act of 1992 to constitutionalise Municipalities. 74th Amendment Act of 1992. The Act added a new Part IX-A, Art 243-P to 243-ZG. Also added a 12th Schedule with 18 functional items of Municipalities. Salient Features are as follows : Three types of Municipalities : Nagar Panchayat – for an area in transition from rural to urban area. Municipal Council – for a smaller urban area. Municipal Corporation – for a larger Urban Area. Composition : all members are directly elected, each representing a ward within the municipal area. State Leg can provide manner of election of Chairperson. State Leg may provide for representation of local MPs, MLAs & locally registered MLCs & Chairpersons of committees (except ward comm.). Ward Committees : Consists of 1 or more wards having 3 lakh people or more. State Leg decides composition, selection of candidates, Territorial area. State Leg may also provide for any other committee. Reservation of seats : Reservation of seats for SCs & STs on basis of population. 1/3rd seats for women. State Leg may provide for reservation for Chairpersons office for SCs, STs and women. May reserve for OBCs also. Duration of Municipalities : fixed 5 yr term, in case of dissolution elections must be conducted in 6 months. New municipality sfter dissolution will only continue for remainder of 5yr term. Disqualifications : can be disqualified under a law for elections to the legislature, or under laws made by State Leg. Minimum age is 21 years. State Election Commission : elections to be conducted by this body. Powers & Functions : State Leg may give any power to the Municipalities as it sees fit. These powers may include all or some of 18 matters in 12th Sch. Finances : State Leg may provide Municipalities with powers to collect taxes & appropriate them, assign revenue collected by State, make grants-in-aid, constitute funds to credit Municipal expenditure. Finance Commission : shall function similarly as it does for Panchayats. Audit of Accounts : State Leg may make provisions regarding maintenance of accounts and their audits. Application to UTs : Prez may direct that the provisions of this act should apply to UTs with appropriate modifications. Exempted Areas : Does not apply to Scheduled areas & Tribal areas in the States. It also doesn’t apply to Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council. District Planning Committee : Every district will have such a committee to consolidate the plans prepared by Panchayats and Municipalities in the district, and to prepare draft development plan for the district as a whole. Metropolitan Planning Committee : Every metropolitan area shall have a committee to prepare a draft development plan. Bar to Judicial interference : the Act bars Judicial interference into electoral including delimitation of constituency matters of Municipalities. Types of Urban Government. Eight types of Urban Local Bodies are as follows : Municipal Corporation. Municipality. Notified Area Committee. Town Area Committee. Cantonment Board. Township. Port Trust. Special Purpose Agency. Municipal Corporation. Created for administration of big cities like Delhi, Mumbai & others. Estb in States by Acts of State Leg & in UTs by Parliament. Municipal Corporation has three authorities : The Council : deliberative & Legislative wing of the Corp. Consists of directly elected as well as nominated members. The composition is governed by the 74th Amendment Act. Council is headed by Mayor assisted by Deputy Mayor elected for 1 year & is a formal head only. The Standing Committees : created to look into different fields to facilitate the working of the Council which is too large. The Municipal Commissioner : is responsible for implementation of decisions taken by the Council & its committees. Is appointed by the State Govt and is generally an IAS officer. Municipality. Are established for administration of towns and smaller cities. Set up in States by State Leg & in UTs by Parliament. They are known by various names like Municipal Council, Municipal Committee, Municipal Board, Borough Municipality, City Municipality & others. It has three authorities : The Council : acts as deliberative & Legislative body. Consists of directly elected councillors. Council is headed by a President /Chairman assisted by a Vice-President /deputy chairman. Unlike the mayor, the post of the President is pivotal. The president enjoys executive powers. The standing committees : created to facilitate working of the Council. The Chief Municipal Officer : is appointed by the state & is incharge of day-to-day General administration of the municipality. Notified Area Committee Created for administration of 2 types of areas : a fast developing town due to industrialisation & a town considered to be important by State Govt but doesn’t qualify for a municipality. It is established by a notification in the government Gazette. It functions under State Municipal Act, but only those provisions mentioned in the notification apply. It can also have powers under other acts. Powers are almost equivalent to a municipality. It is an entirely nominated body, including the chairman, by the State Govt. Thus it is neither an elected body nor a statutory one. Town Area Committee. Set up for administration of a small town. It is a semi-municipal authority with limited civic functions like drainage, roads, street lighting & conservancy. Created by a separate act of the State Legislature. The composition, functions & other matters of the committee are governed by the Act. It may be wholly elected or wholly nominated, or partially elected or partially nominated. Cantonment Board. Established for municipal admin for civilian population in Cantonment area. Set up under the Cantonment Act of 2006 enacted by the Centre. Works under administrative control of the Defence ministry in the Union. It consists of partly elected & partly nominated members. Elected members hold office for 5 yrs while nominated members continue as long as they posted at the Cantonment. Commanding officer of the station is the ex-officio President while VP is elected from among themselves for 5 yrs. Similar functions to Municipalities. Executive officer is appointed by the President of India. Township. These are established by large public enterprises to provide civic amenities to its staff & workers living in housing colonies near the plant. The enterprise appoints a town administrator who is assisted by some engineers & other technical & non-technical staff. Township has no elected members. It is an extension of the bureaucratic structure of the enterprise. Port Trust. Port Trusts are established in Port areas like Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai, etc. They serve two purposes : To protect & manage the port. To provide civic amenities. A port trust is created by an Act of the Parliament. Consists of both Elected & Nominated members. Chairman is an government Official. Civic functions are more or less similar to Municipalities. Special Purpose Agency. Set up by States as function-based and not area-based body. It is incharge of only one function and has purview over only that matter. Such bodies include : Town improvement trust. Urban development authorities. Water supply and sewage boards. Housing boards. Pollution control boards. Electricity supply boards. City transport boards. Estb through State Leg acts. Function independently from Municipalities or Corporations. Central Council of Local Government. Set up in 1954. Constituted under Art 263. Originally dealt with matters of both rural & urban local Govt. Since 1958 is only dealing with urban local government. The council is an advisory body. Consists of Union Minister for Urban Development & State ministers for local self Govt. Makes recommendations on policy matters, making proposals for legislations, drawing up common plan of action, etc.

Panchayati Raj means rural local self-government. Panchayati Raj has been established in all States of India through State Laws. This system was constitutionalised through the 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act of 1992. Evolution of Panchayati Raj. Balwant Rai Mehta Committee. Estb in 1957 to examine working of Community Development Programme (1952) & National Extension Service (1953). Committee submitted report in Nov 1957, made several recommendations : Estb of 3 tier Panchayati Raj system – Gram Panchayat at village, Panchayat Samiti at block, Zila Parishad at district level. Village panchayat should have directly elected representatives, Panchayat Samiti & Zila Parishad to have indirectly Elected representatives. All planning & development activities should be entrusted to these bodies. Panchayat Samiti should be executive body, Zila Parishad should be advisory, coordinating & supervisory body. District collector should be chairman of Zila Parishad. Provide genuine transfer of power to these bodies with adequate resources. System should be evolved to further effect devolution of authority in future. The Balwant Rai Mehta Committee recommendations were accepted by the National Development Council in January 1958. The council allowed States to implement the Panchayati Raj system by modifying it to suit their own needs, but keeping the same basic principles. Rajasthan estb first Panchayati Raj in Nagaur district. The system was different from State to state. Some States like Rajasthan adopted the Three-tier system while other like Tamil Nadu adopted a 2-tier system. West Bengal adopted a 4-tier system. Some States also established nyaya panchayats to try petty civil & criminal cases. Since 1960s several other Study teams, groups, committees were established to examine the various aspects of the system and to help in identifying key areas for improvement. Ashok Mehta Committee. In Dec 1977, Janata Govt appointed the committee which submitted its report on Panchayati Raj in August, 1978, making several recommendations : 3-tier system should be replaced with 2-tier system with Zila Parishad followed by Mandal Panchayat consisting of group of villages. Zila Parishad should be executive body incharge of planning. Panchayati Raj institutions should have compulsory powers of taxation. Regular social audits by District level agencies to ensure expenditure of funds for allotted issues. Nyaya Panchayats should be kept separate, headed by qualified judge. Seats for SCs & STs should be reserved on the basis of their population. Voluntary agencies should play a wider role in strengthening the system. A minister in the State CoM should be appointed for Panchayati Raj. Panchayati Raj must be accorded with a Constitutional recognition. No action was taken since Janata Govt collapsed soon after. G V K Rao Committee. Appointed by Planning Commission in 1985. Following Recommendations : Zila Parishad should be of pivotal importance for Decentralisation of powers. Panchayati Raj inst. should be given more powers to plan development. Some planning functions should be transferred from State to District. Post of District Development Commissioner should be created to act as CEO of Zila Parishad incharge of all development departments in district. Elections to Panchayati Raj institutions should be held regularly. L M Singhvi Committee. Appointed in 1986 by Centre. It made following recommendations : Panchayati Raj inst should be constitutionally recognised. A new chapter should be added in the Constitution for this purpose. Constitutional provisions should be made to ensure regular, free & fair elections to Panchayati Raj bodies. Villages should be reorganised to make Gram Panchayats more viable. Highlighted importance of Gram Sabha. Village panchayats should have more resources. Judicial tribunals should be set up in each State to adjudicate controversies regarding elections. Thungon Committee. Estb through Parliament 1988. Made following recommendations : Panchayati Raj institutions should be constitutionally recognised. 3-tier system at village, block & District Levels should be established. Zila Parishad should be pivotal. Panchayati Raj institutions should have a fixed term of 5 years. Planning & coordination Committee with minister as Head and Zila Parishad presidents as members should be set up. Detailed list of subjects for Panchayati Raj institutions should be incorporated in the Constitution. Reservation on all 3 tiers should be based on population. Reservation should also be provided for women. A State Finance Commission should be set up for devolution of finances to the Panchayati Raj institutions. District Collector should be CEO of Zila Parishad. Gadgil Committee. Estb by Centre in 1988. Made following recommendations : Bestow Constitutional status on Panchayati Raj institutions. 3-tier system should be established. Fixed term of 5 years. Members at all three tiers should be directly elected. Reservation for SCs, STs and women. List of subjects should be specified in the Constitution. Panchayati Raj institutions should be empowered to levy, collect & appropriate taxes. Estb of State Finance Commission. Estb of State Election Commission for the conduction of elections. The above recommendations became the basis for drafting a Constitutional Amendment to incorporate Panchayati Raj into the the Constitution. Constitutionalisation. Rajiv Gandhi Govt : Introduced 64th Const Amd in 1989. Lok Sabha passed the Bill but Rajya Sabha rejected it. V P Singh Govt : in June 1990, in a 2 day conference of State chief Ministers was held to discuss issues relating to strengthening the Panchayati Raj institutions.
