The Conference approved the proposal for fresh introduction of Constitutional Amendment. The fall of the Govt resulted in the lapse of the Bill. Narasimha Rao Govt : reintroduced Constitutional Amendment after deleting controversial aspects of the Bill in September 1991. The Bill was finally passed and became the 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act of 1992. 73rd Amendment Act of 1992. Significance of the Act. Act added a new Part-IX to the Constitution entitled as ‘The Panchayats’. Consists of Article 243 to 243 O. Also added a new Eleventh Schedule. The Act gives shape to Art 40 which directs State to estb Panchayats. Gives Constitutional status to the Panchayati Raj institutions. Provisions of the Act can be grouped into two – Compulsory & Voluntary. Compulsory provisions must be incorporated by States in the laws creating Panchayati Raj institutions, while Voluntary provisions may be included at the discretion of the States. Salient Features. Gram Sabha : The Act make Gram Sabha consisting of registered voters in the area as the foundation of Panchayati Raj. Its powers & Functions are to be determined by the State Legislature. Three-tier System : institutions provided at village, intermediate, & District level. States having less than 20 lakh people may skip intermediate level. Election of Members & Chairpersons : Members at all levels are directly elected. Chairperson of intermediate, District level will be indirectly elected. Chairperson of village level shall elected as State Leg determines. Reservation of Seats : Reservation based on population for SCs & STs on all 3 levels. State Leg to provide reservations in the offices of Chairpersons. 1/3rd of seats reserved in all categories for women, further 1/3rd of Chairperson offices at each level shall be reserved for women. Duration : fixed term of 5 years for all levels & elections must be conducted before term completion . Can be dissolved earlier but fresh elections will be conducted within 6 months. New Panchayat constituted after dissolution will continue only for remainder of 5 year term of last Panchayat. Disqualifications : can be disqualified under any law made for the election to legislature of the state/ under any State Leg law. Minimum age is 21 years. State Election Commission : elections to be conducted by the State Election Commission consisting of a commissioner appointed by the Governor. Commissioner can be removed in the same way as a HC judge. Fixed service conditions for the entire term of Office. Powers & Functions : State Leg determines the power & Functions (including 29 matters in 11th schedule) of Panchayats at all levels. Finances : State Leg may authorise Panchayats to levy, collect & appropriate taxes/ assign taxes & Revenue collected by State / make grants-in-aid / assign a fund for crediting expenses of the Panchayat. Finance Commission : Gov after every 5 yrs will constitute a Finance Commission to recommend the distribution of revenue, determination of taxes assigned to Panchayats, Grants-in-Aid to Panchayats. Also – measures to improve finances of Panchayats, other matters referred by Gov. State Leg will decide qualifications & composition. Central Finance Commission can recommend measures for Panchayat’s financial improvement. Audit of Accounts : State Leg can make provisions regarding audit. Application to UTs : Prez may direct so with modifications. Exempted States & Areas : Act doesn’t apply to J&K, Nagaland, Meghalaya & Mizoram. Exempted areas include Scheduled areas & Tribal areas of States, Hill Areas of Manipur which has a District Council, Darjeeling in West Bengal which has Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council. Parliament may extend the act to the Scheduled & Tribal areas of States. Judicial interference : judiciary is barred from interference in any electoral matters of Panchayats including laws for delimitation. Eleventh Schedule. Mentions subjects under the purview of the PRIs : Agriculture / Land improvement, implementation of Land Reform, land consolidation, soil conservation / Minor Irrigation, water management, watershed development / Animal husbandry, dairying, poultry / Fisheries / Social forestry & farm forestry / Minor forest produce / small scale industries, including food processing industries / Khadi, village & cottage industries / Rural Housing / Drinking Water / Fuel & Fodder. Roads, culverts, waterways, & other means of communication / Rural electrification, including distribution / non-conventional energy sources / poverty alleviation programmes / education including primary & secondary / technical training & vocational education / Adult & non-formal education / libraries / Cultural activities / Markets & fairs / Health & sanitation / Family Welfare / Women & Child development / social welfare / Welfare of weaker sections / Public distribution system / Maintenance of Community assets. Compulsory & Voluntary provisions of the Act. Compulsory Provisions : Organisation of Gram Sabha in villages or group of villages / Estb of 3-tier Panchayats / direct elections at all levels / indirect elections to Chairpersons at intermediate & District level / 21 years as minimum age / Reservation of seats for SCs & STs on all levels / 1/3rd reservation for women at all levels / fixed 5 yr tenure, & holding fresh election within 6 months of dissolution / Estb of State Election Commission / constitute a State Finance Commission. Voluntary Provisions : Giving representation to MPs & Members of State Leg at different levels in their constituencies / providing reservation of seats for OBCs / Granting autonomous powers to Panchayats / Devolution of powers & allowing all or some of 29 functions listed in the 11th schedule to be performed by Panchayats / Granting Financial Powers to the Panchayats. PESA Act of 1996 (Extension Act). Provisions of Part IX relating to Panchayats are not applicable to 5th Schedule areas. But Parliament has powers to extend the same through a law. Under this Provision, Parl enacted the ‘Provisions of the Panchayat (Extension to the Scheduled Areas)’ 1996. At present 10 States have 5th Schedule Areas. The Act extended provisions relating to Panchayats in Part IX with certain modifications. The Act allows Panchayati Raj institutions to be established in these areas without hampering the local traditions & customs, allowing for suitable modifications & restrictions to be placed. Gram Sabha has been given additional importance with responsibility of protecting the local custom and traditions & Powers to approve all plans & projects to be implemented at the village level. Reasons for ineffective performance. Lack of adequate devolution. Excessive control by bureaucracy. Tied nature of funds. Overwhelming dependency on Government funding. Reluctance to use fiscal powers. Status of the Gram Sabha. Creation of parallel bodies like Parliamentary bodies. Poor infrastructure.

Introduction. Article 371 to 371-J in Part XXI lays down special provisions for 12 States : Maharashtra, Gujarat, Nagaland, Assam, Manipur, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Sikkim, Mizoram, Arunachal Pradesh, Goa & Karnataka. The reasoning behind the provision is to help : uplift the people of the backward regions of the States. to protect the cultural and economic interests of the tribal people of the State. To deal with the disturbed law & order condition in some parts of the State. To protect the interests of the local people of the State. These provisions were not mentioned in the orignal Constitution. Provisions for Maharashtra & Gujarat : President is authorised to provide the Govs of Maharashtra and Gujarat with Special responsibility for establishing separate development boards in certain areas of the States, making a provision for an annual report from these boards, allocating funds for development in such areas, provisions for adequate facilities for technical education, vocational training, employment. Provisions for Nagaland : Parliamentary laws on matters relating to religious or social practices of Nagas, Naga customary law & procedure, admin of civil & criminal justice according to customary law, ownership & transfer of land & resources. Gov of Nagaland has special responsibility for law & order to tackle internal disturbances caused by Naga. This power shall cease on the Prez’s say so. Gov has to ensure that the funds provided by Centre are used only for the specific purpose originally assigned for it. Oth/other special provisions for the Tuensang District of Nagaland. Assam : 371-B empowers Prez to create a committee of Leg Assembly consisting of elected members from Tribal areas & other members. Manipur : Article 371-C provides for Prez to make a committee of members elected from Hill areas of the State. Prez can direct Gov to ensure its proper functioning, and can ask an annual report on admin of Hill Areas. Centre can also give directions to State on admin of Hill Areas. Provisions for Andhra Pradesh or Telangana : Article 371-D contain special provisions for Andhra Pradesh (extended to Telangana) : President is empowered to provide equitable opportunities for people belonging to different parts in matters of Public Employment, education.For the above, Prez may require State Govt to organise civil posts in local cadres & provide for direct recruitment. Prez may also specify parts which will be regarded as local areas for admission to educational institutions. Prez may create or abolish an Administrative Tribunal. 371-E provides Parl to estb Central University in Andhra Pradesh. Provisions for Sikkim : Article 371-F contains special provisions for Sikkim – Sikkim Legislative Assembly will consist of not less than 30 members. 1 seat in Lok Sabha is alloted to Sikkim. For protection of interests of different sections of the population, Parliament is empowered to provide the number of reserved seats for such sections & delimitation of constituencies reserved for such sections. Governor shall have special responsibility for maintaining peace & uplifting backward sections of society. In doing this Gov shall have discretion. Prez can extend any law (with modification) active in other States to Sikkim. Provisions for Mizoram : Article 371-G – Acts of Parl on matters relating to religious or social practices of Mizos, Mizo customary law & procedure, admin of civil & criminal in accordance to customary law, ownership & transfer of land, would not apply unless approved by Mizoram Legislative Assembly. Mizoram Leg Assembly is to consist not less than 40 members. Provisions for Arunachal Pradesh : Article 371-H – Gov shall have special responsibility for law & order in the State. In discharge of this, Gov in consultation with CoM shall have personal discretion and the decision shall be final. Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly should not consist of less than 30 members. Provisions for Goa : Article 371-I is to consist not less than 30 members. Provisions for Karnataka : Article 371-J – Gov shall have responsibility for Estb of separate development board for Hyderabad-Karnataka region. Ensuring submission of annual report by board to State Leg Assembly. Equitable allocation of funds for development expenditure. Reservation of seats in educational institutions for students belonging to the region. Reservations in State Govt posts for people belonging to the region.

Introduction. Article 1 declares J&K as a State of India and a part of the territory of India. Article 370 in Part-XXI grants a special status to J&K. Not all parts of the Constitution applies to J&K. It is the only State which has its own Constitution – the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir. The ‘Instrument of Accession of Jammu and Kashmir to India’ signed by Nehru & Hari Singh declared that J&K surrendered only 3 subjects including defence, external affairs & communications to India. India committed that people of J&K will have right to decide extent of Central powers in the State regarding internal affairs. In pursuance of this commitment, Article 370 was incorporated as a temporary measure. Article 370 allows the President to cease the operation of Article 370 but only with the prior recommendation of the Constituent Assembly of J&K. President can also allow application of other Articles of Const in concurrence with the State Govt. Present Relationship of India with J&K. J&K is a State of Indian Union but its name, boundary, area cannot be changed without the consent of the state legislature. J&K has its own Const. so Part-Vl dealing with State Govts doesn’t apply. Parl can make laws on most Union subjects & quite a few Concurrent subjects. But Residuary powers lie with the State except in matters of prevention of terrorism, insult to national flag, anthem, etc. Preventive Detention laws made by Parliament are not applicable to J&K. Fundamental Right to property is still guaranteed in the State along with other fundamental rights in Part-III. Part-IV (DPSP) & Part-IVA (Fundamental Duties) are not applicable. National Emergency won’t have effect without concurrence of State Govt. President can’t declare Financial Emergency. President cannot declare President’s Rule if the Govt fails to comply with the directions of the Centre. President’s Rule can be imposed on the grounds of failure of Constitutional Machinery under provisions of the State Const & not Indian Const. Governor’s Rule can also be declared under the State Constitution. International agreement affecting the disposition of J&K can only be made by Centre with consent of the State Govt. Constitutional Amendment does not apply to the State until it is extended by the President. Fifth Schedule (scheduled areas) & Sixth Schedule (tribal areas) are not applicable. High Court can issue writs only for enforcement of Fundamental Rights & not any other purpose. J&K has much greater measure of autonomy & power in comparison to other States. Centre’s jurisdiction in the State is more limited in comparison ot other States. Features of J&K Constitution. In Sep-Oct 1951, Constituent Assembly of J&K was elected by the people of J&K on the basis adult franchise. The Constitution of J&K was adopted on 17 November, 1956 & came into force on 26th January, 1957. Salient Features are as follows : Declares J&K as integral part of India. Secures justice, liberty, equality & Fraternity to the people of J&K. States that J&K comprises of all territory that was under the ruler including PoK. Defines who shall be termed as ‘permanent citizen’ of the State. Thus definition can only be changed by the State Legislature. Consists of its own list of Directive Principles. Provides for bicameral legislature with Governor as an integral part. Vests the executive powers in the Governor & provides for CM & CoM to aid and advice the Governor. Establishes a High Court consisting of a chief justice & 2 or more other judges. The HC judges are appointed by Prez in consultation with the CJI & Gov of the State. HC enjoys all powers as other HCs however it can only issue writs to enforce Fundamental Rights and not for any other purpose. It provides for Governor’s Rule. The Governor with the concurrence of the President can assume all powers of the State Govt except those of the HC. Gov can dissolve the assembly, dismiss the council of Ministers. Gov’s Rule can be imposed when administration cannot be carried out in accordance with J&K Constitution. Declares Urdu as the official language of the State. Lays down procedure for amendment. Can be amended by a bill passed in each House by a 2/3rd majority of the total membership. However the relationship of the State with the Union cannot be amended. Interlocutors for J&K. On June 26, 2000, Jammu and Kashmir Legislative Assembly adopted a resolution giving itself greater Autonomy, trying to restore the pre-1953 status. This resolution was rejected by the Union Cabinet, however it did commit to greater devolution of powers. In 2010, the government appointed a Group of Interlocutors under the chairmanship of Dileep Padgaonkar in order to hold discussions with all section of J&K and find viable solutions to the State’s problems. In 2011, this group submitted its report making several recommendations including establishment of a Constitutional Committee to review all Central Acts regarding J&K since 1952. Further recommendations were made regarding Art 356, appointment of Governor, Civil Services, etc. These recommendations are yet to be implemented. In 2017, Dineshwar Sharma was appointed as interlocutor to J&K.

Introduction. Subordinate courts function under the High Court at district & lower levels. Article 233 to 237 in Part-Vl deals with Subordinate courts. Organisational structure, jurisdiction & nomenclature of Subordinate courts are laid down by the States so differ from state to state. Broadly there are 3 tiers of Civil & criminal courts below HC : District (civil) & Sessions (criminal) Judge’s Courts. Civil side consists of Subordinate Courts followed by Munsiff’s Court. Criminal side consists of Chief Judicial Magistrate’s Courts followed by Judicial Magistrate’s courts. District Judge. Highest Judicial Authority in the district. Possesses original & appellate Jurisdiction in both civil as well as criminal matters. When dealing with civil cases – known as District Judge, When dealing with Criminal cases – known as Sessions Judge. Has supervisory powers over all Subordinate courts. Sessions judge can impose any sentence including death, however HC has to confirm all capital punishments passed by Sessions judge. Subordinate Courts. Civil Side : Below District Judge is the Court of Subordinate Judge (civil judge) who exercises unlimited pecuniary jurisdiction over civil suits. On the lowest level is the Court of Munsiff. The Munsiff has limited jurisdiction & decides civil cases of small pecuniary stake. Criminal Side : Below the Sessions Judge is the Court of the Chief Judicial Magistrate. The CJM deals with criminal cases which are punishable by imprisonment upto 7 years. At the lowest level is the Court of Judicial Magistrate which deals with Criminal cases punishable by imprisonment upto 3 years. In some states, Panchayat Courts also try petty civil & criminal cases. Such courts are known with varied names such as Nyaya Panchayat, Gram Kutchery, etc. National Legal Services Authority. Article 39A provides for free legal aid for the poor & weaker sections of the society. In 1987, Parliament enacted the Legal Services Authorities Act. This Act established the Legal Services Authorities & Committees at National, State & District Levels. The NALSA monitors implementation of legal aid programmes at the national level & lays down policies & principles for making legal aid & services available under the Act. Legal Services Committees have also been established at the Supreme Court & the High Courts to administer & implement the legal services programme in relation to the the respective courts. Lok Adalats. Lok Adalats are forums where cases or disputes pending in the courts or which are at pre-litigation stage are compromised or settled in an amicable manner. Lok Adalat is a form of the Alternative Dispute Resolution System. First Lok Adalat camp was organised in Gujarat in 1982. Lok Adalats were given a statutory status through the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. Offences which are not compoundable under any law are outside the purview of Lok Adalats. Pending Cases can be brought to Lok Adalat if all parties involved agree to the same. If on application of one of the parties, the court allows for the case to be sent to a Lok Adalat. Lok Adalats have same powers as a Civil Court and its awards are final and binding on all parties without appeal. Lok Adalats. Lok Adalats are forums where cases or disputes pending in the courts or which are at pre-litigation stage are compromised or settled in an amicable manner. Lok Adalat is a form of the Alternative Dispute Resolution System. First Lok Adalat camp was organised in Gujarat in 1982. Lok Adalats were given a statutory status through the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. Offences which are not compoundable under any law are outside the purview of Lok Adalats. Pending Cases can be brought to Lok Adalat if all parties involved agree to the same. If on application of one of the parties, the court allows for the case to be sent to a Lok Adalat. Lok Adalats have same powers as a Civil Court and its awards are final and binding on all parties without appeal. Family Courts. Family Courts Act, 1984 was enacted to establish Family Courts to provide speedy resolutions to disputes relating to marriage & family affairs. Family Courts deal exclusively with family matters therefore holding an expertise in resolving such matters. They are inexpensive & provide a flexible & informal atmosphere to conduct the proceedings. Family Courts Act provides for estb of Family Courts by State Govts in consultation with HCs. Obligatory in all cities & towns with a population of 1 million or above. Family Courts have exclusive jurisdiction over certain family cases including matrimonial relief, divorce, custody of a minor, maintenance of wife, children & parents, etc. Obligatory for Family Courts in the first instance to effect a reconciliation or settlement between the disputing parties. Right to appeal against a Family Court lies inly before High Court. Gram Nyayalayas. Gram Nyayalayas Act, 2008 was enacted to establish Gram Nyayalayas to provide justice to citizens at their door step. These are courts of a Judicial Magistrate first class who is appointed as Nyayadhikari by State Govt in consultation with HC. Gram Nyayalayas are established at the Panchayat level and are mobile courts exercising powers of both Criminal & Civil courts. They go to villages to dispose off cases. Appeal in all criminal cases shall lie in the Sessions court which has to dispose the same within 6 months. Appeal in all Civil cases will lie in the District Court which has to dispose the same in 6 months.

Introduction. In the Single Integrated Judicial system of India, High Courts operate under the Supreme Court of India. High Court is the head of Judicial administration in a state. Constitution provides for a High Court for each State, however Parliament is authorised to provide for a common HC for 2 or more States. Article 214 to 231 of Part-VI deals with High Courts. President appoints judges of the High Court. President also determines the strength of a HC. Judges. Appointment : Judges appointed by President. Chief Justice is appointed in consultation with CJI & Gov(s) of State(s). Other judges are appointed in consultation with CJI, CJ of HC, & Gov. In Third Judges case, SC made the opinion of Collegium binding on Prez. Qualifications : Should be a Citizen/ Should have held Judicial office in India for 10 years or should have been HC advocate of 10 years. Oath : sworn in by the Governor or a person appointed by the Gov. Tenure : Holds office until 62 yr. Questions regarding age of HC judge is decided finally by Prez after consultation with CJI. Can resign by writing to President. Can be removed from Office by Prez on recommendation of Parliament. Vacates office when appointed as SC judge or is transferred. Removal of Judges : HC judges are removed in same manner as SC judges. Removal motion signed by 100 members (LS) or 50 members (RS) is given to Speaker/Chairman. Speaker/Chairman may or may not admit motion. If admitted, 3 member Committee, consisting of CJI/SC judge & CJ of HC & a distinguished jurist, is formed by Speaker to investigate charges. If Committee finds judge guilty of misbehaviour or incapacity, then House takes up the motion for consideration. Each House passes resolution by Special Majority. If passed, an Address is presented to Prez recommending removal of judge. Prez passes an order removing the judge. Salary & Allowances : determined by Parliament. Cannot be reduced except during financial emergency. Retired Judges are entitled to 50% of salary as pension. Acting Chief Justice : Prez can appoint a HC judge as Acting CJ when : When office of CJ is vacant / CJ is temporarily absent / CJ is unable to perform duties of the office. Additional & Acting Judges : Appointed by Prez. Additional judges are appointed temporarily when there is temporary increase in business or when there is arrear of work in HC. Acting Judges are appointed temporarily when a judge is unable to perform duties, or is appointed to act temporarily as CJ of HC. Additional & Acting judges have to meet all qualifications for HC judge. Retired Judges : the CJ of HC can ask any retired judge of any HC to act as a judge of the HC. Prior consent of President is must. President determines the allowances of a such a judge. Such a judge shall enjoy all powers of a judge of HC. Independence of High Court. Mode of Appointment restricts political influence. Security of tenure due to difficult impeachment process. Fixed Service conditions. Expenses charged on Consolidated Fund of State. Conduct of judges cannot be discussed. Ban on practice after retirement. Power to punish for its contempt. Freedom to appoint its staff. Its jurisdiction cannot be curtailed. Separation from executive. Jurisdiction. Constitution does not detail the powers & jurisdiction of the High Courts in detail. Derived from a mixture of Constitutional provisions, Acts of Parliament & State Legislatures, & Powers enjoyed by HCs before independence. The jurisdiction & Powers of HC consist of following : Original Jurisdiction. Writ Jurisdiction. Appellate Jurisdiction. Supervisory Jurisdiction. Control over Subordinate courts. Court of Record Judicial Review. Original Jurisdiction. HC can hear disputes on such matters directly & not by way of appeal. These matters include : Matters of admiralty, will, marriage, divorce, company laws, contempt of court. Disputes regarding election of MPs & members of State Legislatures. Regarding revenue matters. Enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Cases transferred from Subordinate courts requiring interpretation of Constitution. Calcutta, Bombay, Madras & Delhi High Courts have original civil jurisdiction in cases of higher value. Writ Jurisdiction. Art 226 empowers HCs to issue writs. Writs include Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Certiorari, Prohibition & Quo Warranto. Unlike SC, HCs can issue writs not only to enforce Fundamental Rights but also ordinary legal rights. Writ Jurisdiction of HC is not exclusive but in concurrence with the writ Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court. Appellate Jurisdiction. HC can hear cases of Civil & criminal nature by appeal. In Civil Cases : First appeal can be made on both questions of law & fact. Second appeal is made only on questions of law and not fact. Calcutta, Bombay & Madras HCs have intra-Court appeals where a single judge bench order can be appealed in front of a division bench. Decisions of Administrative & other tribunals can be made in front of a division bench of HC. In Criminal Matters : In cases of imprisonment for more than 7 years. All Death sentences made by subordinate Court also must be confirmed by HC whether their is an appeal or not. In specific cases in the Criminal Procedure Code; against judgements of additional sessions judge, Judicial/metropolitan magistrate, Supervisory Jurisdiction : HC has wide Supervisory powers over all Subordinate courts & tribunals (except military) on administrative as well as Judicial matters. However this is extraordinary power & therefore used sparingly against excess of jurisdiction, error of law, etc. Control over Subordinate Courts : HC is consulted for appointments, postings, & promotion of District Judges & appointments to Judicial Services. Also has complete administrative control over members of Judicial Services. It’s law is binding on all Subordinate Courts in the State. Court of Record : HC judgements, proceedings & acts are recorded for perpetual memory & can be admitted in Subordinate courts as precedents. HC has powers to punish for contempt of court. Judicial Review : ‘Judicial Review’ term not mentioned in Constitution. Art 13 & 226 confer the power of judicial review to HC if a law or executive act infringes on Fundamental Rights, or is outside of the competence of the authority, or is against Constitutional provisions.

Introduction. Article 168 to 212 of Part VI deal with State Legislature. Some States have a bicameral legislature while other have a unicameral one. Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, UP, Bihar, Maharashtra, Karnataka and J&K have Bicameral Legislature while others have unicameral leg. Constitution provides for Abolition or creation of a Legislative Council in States by the Parliament through Act passed by Simple Majority, if the concerned State LA passes a resolution to that effect with Special Majority. A bicameral legislature is composed of both the Houses and the Governor, while a unicameral legislature consists of only the Legislative Assembly & the Governor. Composition of the Two Houses. Composition of Assembly : Directly elected with max strength being 500 while minimum strength being 60 in all States based on population. Governor can nominate 1 member from Anglo-Indian Community. Reserved seats for SCs & STs on basis of their population in the State. Composition of Council : indirectly Elected, max membership is fixed at 1/3rd of total strength of Leg Assembly and Minimum membership is 40. Parliament has powers to fix the membership number. ⅓ are elected by local bodies like Municipalities & District boards. 1/12 elected by graduates of 3 years standing residing in State. 1/12 elected by teachers of 3 years standing in State teaching in secondary school or above. ⅓ elected by MLAs from amongst non-MLAs. Rest are nominated by Governor from fields of art, lit., science, etc. Proportional Representation by Single Transferable Vote for elections. Duration of the Two Houses. Duration of Assembly : Like Lok Sabha, LA is not a continuing chamber. Normal term is 5 years, however Gov can dissolve house at anytime. Term of LA can be extended by Parl for 1 yr at a time during emergency. Such extention of term ends 6 months after the end of emergency. Duration of Council : Like Rajya Sabha, Legislative Council is a continuing chamber. It cannot be dissolved and is permanent in nature. ⅓ members retire every 2nd year, with every member enjoying a 6 year term in total. Qualifications. Must be a Citizen of India. Must make & subscribe to an oath before person authorised by Elec Comm. Must not be less than 30 yrs for Leg Council & 25 yrs for Leg Assembly. Must possess other qualifications prescribed by Parliament : For election to Council, person must be elector in an assembly constituency ; for nomination by Gov, must be resident of state. For election to Assembly, person must be an elector in an assembly constituency in the state. Must be SC or ST to contest from Reserved seats for respective categories. Disqualifications. Under Constitution person shall be disqualified : If she holds an office of profit or is an undischarged insolvent. If she is of unsound mind and stands so declared by a court. If she is not a citizen of India or has taken foreign citizenship. Can be disqualified under provisions made by Parliament : If found guilty of certain election offences or corrupt practice in election If convicted for an offence with imprisonment of 2 yrs or more. If person fails to lodge an account of election expenses within time. If person has any interests in Govt contracts, works or services. If person is director or managing agent in a company whose atleast 25% share is owned by Govt. If dismissed from Govt service for corruption or disloyalty to State. If convicted for promotion of enmity between groups or for bribery. If punished for preaching or practicing social crimes like dowry, sati, etc. Vacation of Seats. Double Membership : if person is elected to both Houses, one of the seats falls vacant in accordance to a previous law made by the State Legislature. Disqualification : if member is disqualified due to any provision of the Constitution or in a law made by Parliament. Resignation : members may resign by writing to presiding officers of their respective Houses. Absence : House can declare a members seat vacant if the member is absent from the meetings of the House for a period of 60 days without permission. Other Cases : If her election is declared void by the court. If expelled by the House. If elected to office of President or Vice-President. If appointed to office of Governor of a State. Speaker of Legislative Assembly. Speaker is elected by the assembly from amongst its members. Speaker remains in office for the life of the Assembly, unless : He ceases to Member of assembly / Resigns by writing to Deputy Speaker / removed by majority of members after 14 days prior notice. Powers & Duties of the Speaker include : Maintaining order & decorum, conducting & regulating proceedings. Final interpreter of Const, Rules of Procd, leg precedents in Assembly. Adjourns or suspends meeting in absence of quorum. Excercises casting vote in case of a tie. Can allow secret sitting of the House on request of leader of House. Decides whether Bill is Money or Ordinary in nature. Decides on questions of disqualifications under anti-defection law. Appoints chairmen of all committees of Assembly & supervises them. Is Chairman of Business Advisory Committee, Rules Committee, etc. Deputy Speaker of Assembly. Also elected in same manner as the Speaker after the latter’s election. Can be removed in the same manner & vacates office under same conditions as the Speaker. Performs the duties of the Speaker when the Speaker’s office is vacant. Acts as Speaker when the latter is absent from a sitting of the assembly. When acting as Speaker or performing duties, she enjoys all powers of Speaker. Speaker also Nominates from member of the Assembly a ‘panel of chairmen’ who preside over sittings of Assembly when Speaker or Dy Speaker are absent. Chairman & Deputy Chairman of Council. Chairman & Dy Chairman are elected by the Council from its members. Both Chairman & Deputy vacate office if : He ceases to Member of assembly / Resigns by writing to Deputy Chairman (or Vice versa) / removed by majority of members after 14 days prior notice. Power & Functions of Chairman in Council is similar to the Speaker’s in Assembly except in respect it deciding the nature of a bill as a Money Bill. Deputy Chairman performs the duties of Chairman when the latter’s office is vacant. Also acts as Chairman when latter is absent from sitting of House. Chairman nominates from members a ‘panel of Vice-Chairmen’ to preside over meetings of House when both Chairman and Deputy are absent. Sessions of State Legislature. Summoning : Governor summons the Legislature. Max gap between two sessions cannot be over 6 months. Adjournment : Adjournment suspends the work in a sitting for specified time amounting to hours, days or weeks. Adjournment Sine Die means terminating sitting for an unspecified time. These powers lie with the Presiding officer of the Houses. Prorogation : Presiding Officer deckares House adjourned Sine Die when business of the session is complete. The Governor then prorogues the House. Gov can prorogue mid-session as well. Dissolution : Only lower House can be dissolved by Governor in discretion either on the advice of CM or when the CoM lose majority support. Quorum : 10 members or 1/10 of total members, whichever is greater. Language : Const allows Hindi or English. Speaker can allow other Lang. House can decide whether to allow English or not. Legislative Procedure. Ordinary Bills. Bill in Originating House : Ordinary Bill can originate in either House. Passes through 3 stages – First, Second & Third Reading. Bill passed by First House goes to 2nd House in Bicameral Legislature. In unicameral legislature, Bill passed by house goes directly to Governor. Bill in the Second House : goes through First, Second & Third Reading. If passed, Bill goes to Governor for assent. If Bill originates in Assembly & goes to Council, it can pass the Bill as is OR with amendments & return Bill to assembly for reconsideration OR reject the Bill OR may not take action for a max period of 3 months. The Assembly can accept amendments & the Bill is sent to Gov OR it can reject & send the bill back without amendments. If Council has rejected or kept the bill pending, the Assembly can pass the bill again. This time, the Council can keep bill pending for 1 month to either reject or pass with amendments. In all cases, the Bill will go to Governor. When Bill originates in Council & is sent to Assembly which rejects it, the Bill ends. Thus ultimate power for ordinary Bills lie with Assembly. Assent of the Governor : the Governor has 4 alternatives : Governor may give assent to the Bill. Governor may withhold assent. May return bill for reconsideration only once. May reserve bill for President’s consideration. Assent of President : The President may give assent to the Bill. Withhold assent. Return bill for reconsideration. The Bill returned for reconsideration can passed again with or without amendments within 6 months by legislature. If passed, Bill goes back to President, however the Prez has no obligation to accept the Bill passed for the 2nd time. Money Bills. Money Bill can only be introduced in Legislative Assembly by a Minister with the prior recommendation of the President. Once passed by Assembly, the Bill is sent to Council which can pass the Bill or return bill with recommendations within 14 days. Whether the Assembly accepts or rejects these recommendations, the Bill is deemed to have been passed by both Houses and goes to Gov. If Council keeps the bill for longer than 14 days, the Bill is deemed to have been passed by it and is sent to Governor. The Governor can accept, withold assent or reserve bill for Prez. Governor cannot return the Bill. Privileges of State Legislature. Collective Privileges : enjoyed by the House collectively. Right to publish reports, debates, etc, & right to prohibit the same. Can exclude strangers & hold secret sittings. Make its own rules of Procedure. Punish members or outsiders for breach of its privileges. Right to immediate info regarding arrest, detention conviction, imprisonment & release of a member. Can institute inquiries, order attendance of witnesses, send for records. Individual Privileges : enjoyed by members individually. Cannot be arrested 40 days before/after, during session in civil cases. Freedom of Speech in State Legislature bound only by Const & laws. Can refuse to give evidence, appear as a witness in a court during session.

Introduction. Council of Ministers headed by the Chief Minister is the Real Executive Authority in the State. Position of Council of Ministers is established by conventions of a Parliamentary form of Government. Council of Minister are constituted & function in the same way as Council of Ministers at the Centre. Nature of Advice by Ministers. Art 163 provides for existence of CoM headed by CM to advice Governor on all matters, except those for which the Gov is required to act in discretion. Question of whether a matter is under Discretionary Powers of Gov is decided by the Governor as final authority. Advice tendered by Ministers can’t be called into question by any Court. In 1971, SC ruled that a CoM must always exist to advice Gov therefore CoM continues in Office until successor takes charge. Wherever Constitution requires the ‘satisfaction of Governor’, the satisfaction is not personal but of the CoM. Appointment of Ministers. Art 164 provides for appointment of Ministers by Gov on the advice of CM. A minister who is not a member of state legislature must become one within 6 months. A minister can speak and take part in proceedings of both Houses but only vote in which she is a member. Total number of Ministers cannot exceed 15% of strength of Leg Assembly. However, minimum 12 Ministers must in CoM of every State. A disqualified member of legislature on grounds of defection cannot be appointed as a minister. Governor administer oath of office and Ministers serve at her pleasure. Responsibility of Ministers. Collective Responsibility : Art 164 clearly states that CoM is collectively responsible to State Leg Assembly. When leg assembly passes no confidence motion, all ministers from both Houses must resign. Also means that a decision of cabinet is binding on all ministers even if they disagree with it. Ministers must defend the decision in public. Individual Responsibility : Each minister can be individually asked to resign or can be removed by Gov without effecting the CoM as a whole. No Legal Responsibility : As in Centre, Ministers have no legal responsibility for the advice tendered to the Governor.

Introduction. Chief Minister is the de facto executive Head. CM is the head of the Government. CM’s role in State is similar to PM’s role at the Centre. Art 164 – CM shall be appointed by Governor to serve at her pleasure. In accordance with Parliamentary Conventions, Gov must appoint the leader of the majority party as CM. In a hung assembly, Gov uses discretion, generally appointing leader of the largest party or the coalition leader as CM, asking her to prove majority support within 1 month. Governor may also appoint a CM when CM dies in office & no clear successor emerges. CM must become member of either House within 6 months of appointment. Powers in relation to Council of Ministers. Ministers are appointed by Gov on binding advice of the CM. Allocates and reshuffles portfolios in CoM. Can ask Minister to resign or advice Gov to dismiss the Minister. Presides over meetings of CoM. Guides, directs, controls & coordinates activities of all ministers. Can dissolve CoM by resigning since the resignation or death of CM leads to automatic collapse of CoM. Powers in relation to the Governor. CM is principal channel of communication between Gov & CoM : CM communicates to Gov all the decisions of the CoM regarding administration or legislation proposals. Furnishes such info on admin & leg proposals as may be required by Gov. Submits decision of a Minister for the CoM’s consideration when required by the Governor. Advises governor regarding appointment of important officials like advocate-general, chairman & members of SPSC, State Election Commissioner, etc. Relation with Legislature & other powers. CM is leader of the House, in which capacity : CM advises the Gov regarding summoning & proroguing of Leg. Can recommend dissolution of Lower House at any time to the Gov. Announces Government policies on the floor of the House. Chairman of State Planning Board. Vice-chairman of the concerned Zonal Council in rotation for a period of 1 year at a time. Member of Inter-State Council & National Development Council. Chief Spokesman of the State Govt. Crisis manager-in-chief at political level during emergencies. Political head of services.

Introduction. Constitution provides for a Parliamentary form of Govt in the States as well. Part-Vl deals with government in States (except for J&K). Art 153 to 167 deal with State Executive consisting of governor, CM, Council of Ministers & advocate-general of the state. Governor is the chief executive Head of the State. Governor is a nominal head. Governor also acts as an agent of the Centre in the State. 7th Amd of 1956 allows for 1 Gov for more 2 or more States. Appointment, Conditions & Term. Governor is appointed by the President for a maximum term of 5 years. Governor serves at the pleasure of Prez, but is not subordinate to Centre. Gov can resign by handing resignation to Prez. Chief Justice of High Court administers the oath of office. Qualifications & Conditions : Should be a Citizen of or above the age of 35 years. Should not be Member of Leg or Parl. Such a person is deemed to have vacated her office when she enters upon her office as Governor. Should not hold office of profit. Entitled to use of Official Residence (Raj Bhawan). Entitled to emoluments, allowances as decided by Parliament. Emoluments cannot be diminished during the term of Office. Enjoys personal immunity from legal liability for official acts. Immune from criminal proceedings. Civil proceedings after 2 months notice. Executive Powers. All exec actions of State Govt is taken in the Gov’s name. Gov makes rules for authentication of such actions taken in his name. Makes rules for transaction of business and its allocation to ministers. Appoints CM & other ministers to serve at his pleasure. Appoints advocate general of the state to serve at his pleasure. Appoints state election commissioner. Appoints Chairman & members of State Public Service Commissions. Can seek info from CM on admin of State or legislation proposals. Can require CM to submit a Minister’s decision for consideration of CoM. Recommends imposition of Constitutional emergency to Prez in the State. Acts as Chancellor of State Universities & appoints Vice-chancellors. Legislative Powers. Gov can summon or prorogue State Leg & dissolve State Leg Assembly. Can address the State Leg at first session of term and every year. Can send messages to the House or houses regarding a pending bill. Can appoint any member to preside over a house meetings when the offices of Speaker/Chairman & Deputy Speaker/ Deputy Chairman fall vacant. Nominates 1/6th of Members in State LC from fields of art, lit., Sci, etc. Can nominate 1 member to State LA from Anglo-Indian Community. Decides on question of Disqualification in consultation with State EC. When a bill is sent to State Legislature, Governor can : Give assent to the Bill, OR Return Non-Money Bill for reconsideration only once to Leg, OR Reserve the Bill for consideration of Prez, if the bill endangers position of HC (reservation obligatory in this case), if Bill is Ultra-vires, opposed to DPSP, against larger interest of Country, deals with Art 31A. Legislative Powers. Can promulgate Ordinances when State Legislature is not in session. Ordinances must be approved by State Leg within 6 weeks of reassembly. Governor lays the reports of the State Finance Commission, SPSC, & CAG in front of the State Legislature. Financial Powers. Governor sees that the Annual Financial Statement is laid before State Leg. Money Bills can only be introduced with her prior recommendation. Demand for grants can only be made on her recommendation. Gov can make advances out of Contingency Fund of India to meet unforseen expenditure. Constitutes a Finance Commission every five years to review financial position of Panchayats and Municipalities. Judicial Powers. Can grant pardons, reprives, respites & Remissions of punishments or suspend, remit & commute the sentence against laws relating to matters to which exec powers of the State extends. Consulted by Prez while appointing judges of State HCs. Makes appointments, postings & promotions of District Judges in consultation with State HC. Appoints persons to Judicial Services of State in consultation with HC & SPSC. Discretionary Powers. Art 154 envisages the possibility of the Governor acting on discretion. The Constitution doesn’t make ministerial advice to Gov binding on her. Governor has Discretionary Powers on following matters : Reservation of Bill for consideration of Prez. Recommendation for imposition of President’s Rule in the State. While acting as the administrator of an adjoining UT (additional charge). Determining amount payable by certain State Govts to an Autonomous Tribal District Council as royalty for acquiring mineral exploration licence. Seeking info from CM on administrative and Legislative matters. Appointment of CM in a hung assembly or in case of sudden vacation of post. Dismissal of CoM when they cannot prove majority support. Dismissal of State LA when CoM has lost majority. Apart from these there are certain other State-specific matters on which Gov considers the CoM advice but acts finally on her own discretion.

Introduction. Developed in USA in 1960s to give legal representation to the poor, environmentalists, consumers, racial & ethnic minorities, and others. In India, PIL is a product of Judicial Activism in early 1980s. PIL in India was facilitated due to relaxation of rule of ‘locus standi’ (only whose rights are violated can move the court). PIL can be filed by any person having sufficient interest on behalf of those whose rights are being violated and cannot approach the court themselves. Purpose of PIL includes : Vindication of Rule of Law. Providing effective access to justice to socially & economically weaker sections of the society. Meaningful realisation of the Fundamental Rights. Scope of PIL. According to SC’s guidelines, PIL can be filed only on following matters : Bonded Labour matters / Neglected Children / non-payment of wages and Exploitation of workers / Petitions from jail complaining of harassment or for early release, death in jail, transfer, release on personal bond, speedy trial as Fund. Rt / Petitions against police for refusing to register FIR, harassment, & death in custody / Petitions against atrocities on women, harassment of bride, rape murder, kidnapping / Petitions complaining of harassment or torture of SC/ST/OBC villagers by Co-villagers or police / Petitions relating to environmental pollution, drugs, food adulteration, maintenance of heritage and culture, forest and wildlife, other matters of public importance / Petitions from riot victims / Family pension. Principles of PIL. PILs are admitted by SC & HCs in fulfilling their duties under Art 32 & 226. Ordinary Procedural laws are relaxed in order to admit PILs. The Court can invoke Art 14, 21 & Human Rts to protect Rts of people. Common rule of ‘locus standi’ is relaxed to allow representation of poor. If prima facie, PIL shows valid reasons, State may not be allowed by the Court to raise any questions on maintainability of the petition. Dispute between warring groups in realm of private law can not be PIL. However, in appropriate cases, the Court may further enquire into the subject of litigation in public interest, even if the orognal petition was moved for redressal of personal grievance only. Court may appoint investigative Commissions & bodies to enquire into PILs. Court will not transgress into policy & remain within jurisdiction. HC may pass an order to protect Rts but not excercise powers akin to Ar 142.

Introduction. Originated in the USA. Judicial Activism means the proactive role that the judiciary plays to protect the rights of citizens by forcing the other 2 organs of the government to do their Constitutional duty. Judicial Activism can lead sometimes lead to the judiciary overstepping their powers to intrude into Legislative and executive functions and powers. PIL is the most popular form and tool for Judicial Activism. Justification of Judicial Activism. When legislature & Executive fail to do their duties it can lead to collapse of responsible governance. Citizens of the country look up to judiciary to protect their rights & freedoms. This forces judiciary to act to fulfill the needs of the masses. To fill in laws for matters on which no clear legislation exists. To make the difficult and unpopular decisions for greater good when the political parties are not able to do the same durme to fear of losing power. When the basic rights of citizens are not being fulfilled because of lacklustre attitude of the people in power. Activators of Judicial Activism. Civil Rights Activists : focusing on civil & political rights issues. People Rights Activists : working against Government suppression of rights. Consumer Rights groups : raise issues of consumer rights. Citizens for environmental action. Bonded Labour. Rights of Child groups. Custodial Rights Groups : rights for those in prison or police custody. Poverty Rights Groups. Indigenous People’s Rights Groups : rights for tribals and forest dwellers. Women’s Rights Groups. Bar-based Groups : Autonomy & accountability of Indian Judiciary. Media Autonomy Groups. Assorted Lawyer-based Groups : Includes influential lawyers for causes. Assorted individual Petitioners : includes freelance activist individuals. Judicial Restraint. Means that the roles of judges should be limited to saying what the law is and leaving the business of law-making to the legislature & Executive. Supreme Court while delivering a judgement in 2007 called for Judicial Restraint. It said : Judges unjustifiably trying to perform exec or leg functions is unconst. Judges must not overreach and encroach on the domains of other two organs of the government. Courts must realise that administrative authorities are experts in their field while the court is not an administration expert. Other 2 organs not doing their jobs is not reason valid enough since judiciary is also not doing its job of clearing the pending cases. People have the right to correct their Govt by voting, not the judiciary. Encroachment of power will lead to imbalance of power between the organs of the Govt which may lead to similar retaliation from them.

Introduction. Judicial Review is the power of the judiciary (SC & HC) to examine the Constitutional validity of Legislative enactments and executive orders of the Centre & State governments. Judicial Review can be classified into three types : Judicial Review of Constitutional Amendments. Judicial Review of legislation of the Parliament & State Legislatures & Subordinate legislation. Judicial Review of Administrative action of the Union & State authorities under the state. Judicial Review is required in order to uphold the principle of Supremacy of the Constitution, to maintain federal equilibrium, & to protect Fund. Rts. SC has declared Judicial Review as part of the basic structure of the Constitution. Constitutional Provisions for Judicial Review. ‘Judicial Review’ not mentioned in the Constitution. Article 13 declares all laws inconsistent with Fund. Rts. shall be void. This provides for clear grounds for Judicial Review by the Court through interpretation of the Constitution. Article 32 gives the Right to Constitutional Remedies for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights and review of laws or exec acts which violate Rights. Article 226 empowers HCs to issue writs for protection of Fundamental Rights as well as for other matters. Scope of Judicial Review. The Constitutional validity of a Legislative enactment or an executive order can be challenged in the SC or HC on the following 3 grounds : It infringes the Fundamental Rights (Part-lll). It is outside the competence of the authority which has framed it. It is repugnant to the Constitutional provisions. Judicial Review of the 9th Schedule. 1st Const Amd introduced Article 31B which protected acts and regulations included in the 9th Schedule from being challenged on the grounds of violation of Fundamental Rights. In I.R. Coelho case (2007), SC ruled that a law placed in the 9th Schedule after April 24, 1973 cannot violate the Fundamental Rights under Article 14, 15,19 & 21 or the ‘basic structure’ of the Constitution. April 24,1973 was the founding day of the ‘basic structure’ concept through the verdict in the Kesavananda Bharati case.

Introduction. Supreme Court is the head of the integrated Judiciary in India. (adopted from Govt of India Act, 1935). It is the highest court of appeal in India. Article 124 to 147 in Part-V deal with Supreme Court. Consists of 31 judges (30+1 CJI). Judges. Appointment of Judges : Appointed by the President after ‘consultation’ with the CJI & other judges that he deems necessary. Appointment of CJI : In the Second Judges case (1993), SC ruled that senior most judge of the SC should alone be appointed as the CJI. Qualifications of judges : he should be a Citizen. He should have been HC judge for 5 years; OR he should have been HC advocate for 10 years; OR he should be a distinguished jurist in the opinion of the President. Tenure : holds office until the age of 65. He can resign by writing to Prez. Can be removed from office by Prez on recommendation of Parliament. Salaries & Allowances : salaries, allowances, privileges, leave and pension of judges cannot be reduced during their tenure except in financial emergency. Retired judges have a pension equal to 50% of their salary. Removal of Judges. A judge can dismissed from of an office by an order of the Prez. The Prez can give such an order only on the recommendation of Parliament. Two grounds of removal : Proved Misbehaviour or incapacity. The Judges Enquiry Act (1968) regulates the procedure relating to removal of a judge : A removal motion signed by 110 members in LS or 50 members in RS is given to Speaker/Chairman who may or may not admit it. If admitted, a 3 member Committee is appointed by Speaker/Chairman to investigate charges. Committee must consist CJI or SC judge, a CJ of HC, & a distinguished jurist. If Committee finds judge guilty or incapable, house takes up the motion for consideration. Each House must pass the motion by a Special Majority. Only then is advice for removal given to Prez. Acting Chief Justice : Prez can appoint a judge as Acting CJI in cases of vacancy, temporary absence, or incapability. Ad hoc Judge : Prez can appoint a HC judge holding all SC qualifications as an ad hoc judge in consultation with the concerned HC Chief Justice, only when the quorum of permanent judges in SC is lacking. Retired Judges : CJI can at anytime, ask a retired SC or HC judge to act as a Supreme Court judge for a temporary period. CJI needs previous consent of the Prez. Seat of Supreme Court : Constitution declares Delhi as the seat, but gives powers to CJI with approval of Prez to create other seats. Procedure of the Court : SC, with approval of Prez, can make rules of Procedure. Constitutional cases or references made by Prez under Art 143 are decided by a bench of atleast 5 judges. All other cases are decided by a three judge bench or a division bench. Independence of Supreme Court. Constitutional Provisions to ensure independence of SC : Mode of appointment requires consultation with SC. Security of tenure due to removal process requiring Parliamentary approval. Fixed service conditions for life. Expenses charged on Consolidated Fund – no Parliamentary vote needed. Conduct of judges cannot be discussed in Legislature. Ban on practice after retirement. Power to punish for its contempt. Freedom to appoint its own staff. Jurisdiction cannot be curtailed. Separation from executive – Judicial Powers not resting with executive. Jurisdiction Of Supreme Court. The Supreme Court has vast jurisdiction and powers which can be classified into : Original Jurisdiction. Writ Jurisdiction. Appellate Jurisdiction. Advisory Jurisdiction. A Court of Record. Power of Judicial Review. Other Powers. Original Jurisdiction. The SC has exclusive Original Jurisdiction in cases of disputes between : The Centre & one or more states. Centre and any state or states on one side & one or more state on other. Between two or more States. This jurisdiction does not extend to the following : Questions of political nature. (has to be a question of legal right). Suit brought by a Private Citizen against Centre or states. A dispute arising out of a Pre-Constitution treaty, agreement, etc. Dispute arising of such treaty, etc which specifies this jurisdiction limit. Inter-State Water Disputes. Matters referred to the Finance Commission. Adjustment of certain expenses & pensions between Centre & states. Ordinary dispute of commercial nature between Centre & states. Recovery of damages by a state against the Centre. Writ Jurisdiction. Supreme Court is guarantor of Fundamental Rights of Citizens. SC is empowered to issue writs including Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari and Quo-Warranto for enforcing Fund. Rts. However, High Courts also have this power and the original Jurisdiction is not exclusive. A citizen can either approach the SC or HC directly if his or her Fundamental Rights are violated. The Supreme Court can only issue writs to enforce Fundamental Rights while the High Courts have the power to issue writs for other cases as well. Therefore, Writ Jurisdiction of High Courts is wider than that of SC. Appellate Jurisdiction. Supreme Court is highest court of appeal in India. Constitutional Matters : An appeal can be made if HC certifies that the case involves a substantial question of law requiring interpretation of Const. Civil Matters : an appeal can be made if HC certifies that the Case involves a substantial question of law of general importance requiring SC’s decision. Criminal Matters : an appeal is heard against HC judgement if the HC has : (i) on appeal reversed an order of acquittal and given death sentence or imprisonment of 10 years or life; OR (ii) taken any case from a lower court & has convicted & sentenced death or imprisonment for 10 years or life; OR (iii) certified that the case is fit for appeal to the Supreme Court. Further, SC enjoys all other Appellate Jurisdiction in all Civil & Criminal cases which were enjoyed by the Federal Court of India. Appeal by Special Leave : SC can permit appeal for any case on any matter from any Court or Tribunal in the country. This is a discretionary power of SC. Advisory Jurisdiction. Article 143 authorises the Prez to seek opinion of SC in 2 types of matters : On any question of law or fact of Public importance which has arisen or is likely to arise. On any dispute arising out of Pre-Constituion treaty, agreement, engagement, etc. In first case, SC may tender or refuse to tender its opinion to the Prez. In second case, the SC must tender its opinion to the Prez. In both cases, advice or opinion tendered is not binding on the President. A Court of Record. As a Court of Record, SC has 2 powers : Judgements, proceedings & acts of the SC are recorded for perpetual memory. These records are admissible in all courts and cannot be questioned. They are recognised as legal precedents and references. It has power to punish for contempt of court either with simple imprisonment of upto 6 months or ₹2000 fine or both. It has power to punish for contempt of any Court or tribunal in India. Civil Contempt : means wilful disobedience to any order, judgment, etc. Criminal Contempt : means the publication of any matter or doing an act which — (i) scandalises or lowers the authority of the court; OR (ii) prejudices or interferes woth the due course of a judicial proceeding; OR (iii) interferes or obstructs the administration of justice in any other manner. Innocent publication & distribution of some matter, fair and accurate report of proceedings or fair and reasonable criticism of acts are not Contempt. Other Powers. Decides disputes regarding election of Prez & VP. It is the final authority. Enquires into conduct & behaviour of chairman & members of UPSC in a reference made by Prez. If guilty of misbehaviour, it can recommend their removal. SC’s advice in this regard is binding. It has power to review its own judgment. Authorised to withdraw cases pending in HC and dispose them by itself. It can also transfer a case from one HC to another. Its law, decree or order is binding and enforceable through out the country. It is the final interpreter of the Constitution. It has the power of judicial superintendence & control over all courts & tribunals functioning in the country. It has the power of Judicial Review. Supreme Court Advocates. Three categories of advocates are allowed to practise law before SC : Senior Advocates : this a designation awarded by the Supreme Court or a High Court to an advocate who in its opinion is deserving of the same due to her ability, standing at Bar or special knowledge or experience in law. A Senior Advocate is not entitled to appear without an Advocate-on-record in SC or without a junior in any other court or tribunal. Advocates-on-Record : Only these advocates are entitled to file any matter or document before SC. Other Advocates : they are allowed to appear and argue any matter on behalf of a party but they are not entitled to file any document or matter before the Court.

Introduction. The Indian Parliamentary Group acts as a link maintained by India with various Parliaments of the World. Functions as the ‘National Group’ of Inter-Parliamentary Union & main branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. Promotes personal contact among MPs. Arranges lectures, Seminars, discussions, orientation for the benefit of MPs. Addresses by Heads of States to the Parliament are also arranged by this group. The Group gives an award of ‘Outstanding Parliamentarian’ through a 5 member Committee constituted by the Speaker. The Group constitutes Parliamentary Friendship Groups with other countries to encourage bilateral relations. Composition of the Group. IPG is an autonomous body formed in 1949, in pursuance of a motion adopted by Constituent Assembly. Membership is open to all Members of Parliament. Former MPs can also become associate members, or can pay a fixed amount for membership for life. Speaker is the ex-officio President of the Group. Deputy Speaker and Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha are ex-officio Vice-Presidents. Secretary-general of Lok Sabha is the ex-officio Secretary – General of the Group. The Group and IPU. Inter-Parliamentary Union is an International organisation of Parliaments of sovereign states. IPU consists of 153 Parliaments. Its aim is the firm establishment of representative institutions in India. The relationship with IPU as the National Group helps Indian Parliamentary delegations to develop contacts with parliamentarians of other countries. Provides facilities to meet parliamentarians in different countries during tours. Members of IPG are eligible to visit foreign countries as members of Indian Parliamentary delegations to IPU Conferences. Members of the IPG have also been holding important positions in the IPU. The Group and the CPA. Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is an association of about 17000 commonwealth parliamentarians. Its mission is to promote the advancement of Parliamentary democracy by enhancing knowledge & understanding of Democratic governance, and by building an informed parliamentary community, and to further cooperation among commonwealth Parliaments and Legislatures. Major advantages of membership of CPA include : Opportunity for participation in conferences, seminars, visits & exchanges of delegation. Free access to newsletter and information to members of Parliamentary, Constitutional and Commonwealth matters. CPA readily assists in arranging introduction for members visiting other jurisdiction. Members in other countries are accorded Parliamentary courtesies.

Introduction. Parliamentary Forums are platforms for MPs to interact with Ministers concerned, experts, & key officials on various important issues. The forums exist to sensitise MPs on key areas of concern & equip them with latest info, technical know-how, etc in order to raise issues in DRSC. To prepare a data-base on critical issues and circulate such data among MPs. There are 8 Parliamentary Forums at present : Parliamentary Forum on Water Conservation & Management. (2005) Parliamentary Forum on Youth. (2006) Parliamentary Forum on Children. (2006) Parliamentary Forum on Population & Public Health. (2006) Parliamentary Forum on Global Warming & Climate Change (2008) Parliamentary Forum on Disaster Management. (2011) Parliamentary Forum on Artisans and Craftspeople (2013) Parliamentary Forum on Millennium Development Goals (2013) Composition of the forums. The Speaker of Lok Sabha is the ex-officio Chairman of all the Forums except on Population & Public Health – RS Chairman is President while Speaker is Co-President. Deputy Chairman of RS, Deputy Speaker, concerned ministers and Chairman of DSRC are the ex-officio Vice-Presidents of respective Forums. Each forum consists of not more than 30 members (21 – LS / 10 – RS) excluding the President, Co-President and Vice Presidents. Members are nominated by the Speaker & Chairman. Each member remains in office as long as he is a Member of the House. Speaker appoints member-conveners for each forum to conducts the forum meetings. Meetings are held as may be necessary during Parliamentary sessions. Functions of the Forum. Parliamentary Forum On Water Conservation and Management : To identify problems of water and make recommendations. Identifying ways to involve members in conservation of water. To create awareness through seminars & campaigns. Parliamentary Forum on Youth : identifying ways of involving the youth for accelerating development initiatives. To increase awareness among grassroot leaders for potential of youth. To improve Parliament’s youth outreach. To consult experts on redesigning of policies for youth empowerment. Parliamentary Forum on Children : To enhance awareness of MPs towards critical issues affecting children’s well-being. To provide MPs an interface with civil society for highlighting children’s issues and fostering effective strategic partnership with the corporate & voluntary sector to solve such issues. Parliamentary Forum On Population & Public Health : To deliberate strategies for population stabilisation. To prepare strategies on public health. To build greater societal awareness about health and population control. To hold comprehensive dialogues in matters of Public health & population with experts at the national and international level. Parliamentary Forum on Global Warming & Climate Change : To identify problems related to global warming and climate change. Identify ways to involve MPs in such discussions. To organise seminars and workshops to create awareness. Parliamentary Forum on Disaster Management : To identify problems related to disaster management, make suggestions. To identify ways to involve MPs in interactions with specialist bodies in Disaster management. To create awareness through seminars and campaigns. Parliamentary Forum On Artisans and Craftspeople : To enhance awareness of issues faced by artisans and Craftspeople and promote traditional art & crafts. To provide MPs a platform to discuss ideas on such issues. To enable formation of strategic partnerships with voluntary and corporate sector. To hold comprehensive dialogues on matters relating to promotion of traditional arts & crafts. Parliamentary Forum on Millennium Development Goals : To enhance awareness of MPs towards critical issues under Millennium Development Goals. To provide a platform to discuss such issues. To provide an opportunity to MPs to interact with expert organisations dealing with issues under Millennium development goals.

Introduction. The Parliament, due to lack of time and expertise, is unable to make a detailed scrutiny of all Legislative measures and other matters. Therefore Parliamentary Committees are responsible for assisting the Parliament in discharging its duties. Constitution makes mention of these committees but without specific details. Mostly defined by rules of the two houses. A Parliamentary Committee is that : Which is appointed or elected by the House or nominated by the Speaker /Chairman. Works under direction of the Speaker/Chairman. Presents report to House or Speaker/Chairman. Has a Secretariat provided by the Lok Sabha/Rajya Sabha. Can be classified into ‘Ad Hoc Committees’ and ‘Standing Committees’. Ad Hoc Committees. Are temporary in nature and only exist until their specific task is over. Can be divided into two categories : Inquiry & Advisory Committees. Inquiry Committees are constituted by the Houses by adopting a motion, or by the Speaker/Chairman, to inquire into and report on specific subjects. Advisory Committees include select or Joint Committees on bills, which are constituted to consider and report on particular bills. These are only formed to look into Bills. Standing Committees. Standing Committees are permanent in nature. They are reconstituted every year or periodically and work on a continuous basis. On the basis of nature of functions performed by them, Standing Committees can be categorised into : Financial Committees. Departmental Standing Committees. Committees to Inquire. Committees to scrutinise and control. Committees related to day-to-day business of the House. House-keeping Committees or Service Committees. Financial Committees. Public Accounts Committee : 22 members (15 – LS / 7 – RS). Members elected every year through Proportional Representation. Ministers are not elected. Speaker chooses the Chairman. Functions to examine Appropriation and Finance Acc of Union. Analyses the audit report of CAG. Estimates Committee : 30 members from Lok Sabha yearly. No minister. Examines the estimates included in the budget. Provides alternative economic policies and suggestions. Committee on Public Undertakings : 22 (15 – LS /7 – RS) elected yearly. No minister and Only LS member is elected Chairman by Speaker. Examines reports and accounts of public undertakings. Examines whether affairs of public undertakings are being managed properly on the basis of sound business and commercial principles. Departmental Standing Committees. There are 24 Departmentally-Related Standing Committees (DRSCs). Main objective is to secure more accountability of the Executive to the Parliament, particularly financial accountability. Each Committee consists of 31 members (21 – LS / 10 – RS). Members are nominated by the Speaker and Chairman in respective Houses. No ministers. Term of Office is 1 year. 16 Committees function under Lok Sabha & 8 under Rajya Sabha. Examples : Under Rajya Sabha : Committee on Home Affairs / Committee on Commerce / Committee on Health and Family Welfare, etc. Under Lok Sabha : Committee on Defence / Committee on Railways / Committee on Social Justice and Empowerment / Committee on External Affairs / Committee on Finance/Committee on Agriculture, etc. Standing Committees. Standing Committees are permanent in nature. They are reconstituted every year or periodically and work on a continuous basis. On the basis of nature of functions performed by them, Standing Committees can be categorised into : Financial Committees. Departmental Standing Committees. Committees to Inquire. Committees to scrutinise and control. Committees related to day-to-day business of the House. House-keeping Committees or Service Committees. Committees to Inquire. Committees on Petitions : examines petitions on bills & important matters. Also entertains representation from individuals & organisations on matters pertaining to Union Subjects. LS Committee consists of 15 members, RS committee – 10 members. Committee of Privileges : semi-judicial functions. Examines cases of breach of privileges of House or members. Makes recommendations as to the punishment. LS Committee has 15 members, RS committee has 10 members. Ethics Committee : enforces code of conduct of MPs. Examines cases of misconduct. Recommends appropriate actions. Engages in maintaining discipline and decorum in House. Committees to Scrutinize and Control. Committee on Government Assurances : examines assurances & promises made by ministers on the floor of the House & reports on the extent to which they’ve been fulfilled. LS Committee – 15 / RS Committee – 10 members. Committee on Subordinate legislation : Reprorts on whether delegated powers of the Executive are being properly excercised or not. Committee on Papers Laid on the Table : Examines whether papers laid by Ministers on the Table of the House comply with Const or related Act. Committee on Welfare of SCs & STs : Considers reports of National Commission for the SCs & National Commission for the STs, examines all other welfare matters. 30 members (LS – 20 / RS – 10). Committee on Empowerment of Women : Considers reports of National Commission for Women, and other related matters. 30 memb (LS: 20/RS:10). Joint Committee on Offices of Profit : Checks other bodies & orgs for members holding offices and whether it is an Office of Profit. Committees Relating to the Day-to-day Business of the House Business Advisory Committee : Regualtes timetable and programme of the House. Allocates time for transaction of business on various matters. LS has 15 members with Speaker as Chairman, RS has 11 including Chairman. Committee on Private Members’ Bills and Resolutions : Classifies Private Member bills and allocates time for discussion on such bills. LS 15 members with Deputy Speaker as Chairman. RS doesn’t have such committee. Rules Committee : Considers matters of Procedure and conduct of House, recommends amendments to rules of House. LS – 15 members with Speaker as Chairman, RS – 16 members including Chairman. Committee on Absence of Members : considers all applications of members for leave of absence from sittings. Also examines the cases of members who have been absent for over 60 days without permission. LS has 15 members while Rajya Sabha has no such Committee. House-keeping Committees. General Purposes Committee : Considers maters not falling under jurisdiction of any other committee. In each House, the Committee has the Presiding officer as Chairman, Deputy Presiding officers, members of panel of Chairpersons / Vice Chairpersons, Chairpersons of all DRSC, leaders of recognised parties & other members nominated by Presiding officer. House Committee : Deals with residential accommodation of members & other amenities like food and medical aid. Library Committee : Considers matters relating to library of Parliament & assists the members in using the services of the libraries. Joint Committee on salaries and allowances of members : Frames rules for regulating payment of salary, allowances and pension to members of Parliament. Consultative Committees. Consultative Committees are attached to various Ministries /Departments. They consist of members from both the Houses of Parliament. Minister / Minister of State incharge of the ministry acts as chairman. Act as a forum for informal discussions between MPs and Ministers. Committees are constituted by Ministry of Parliamentary Affairs. Membership of these committees is voluntary and is left to the choice of the members and the leaders of their parties. Dissolved upon the end of Lok Sabha Term.

Election and Composition. Parliament is the Legislative Organ of the Union Govt. Occupies pre-eminent & Central position in Indian Democratic Political System dur to the adoption of Parliamentary System. Article 79 to 122 of Part-V deal with the Parliament. Organisation of Parliament. Parliament consists of three parts : President, Rajya Sabha, Lok Sabha. Rajya Sabha represents the States & UTs of India, while Lok Sabha represents the people of India as a whole. President is part of Parliament in the capacity that a Bill only becomes Law with his assent & he summons & prorogues the Parliamentary Sessions, dissolves the Lok Sabha, addresses both Houses & so on. This Organisation of Parliament with the feature of ‘President-in-Parliament’ has been borrowed from Britain. Composition of Rajya Sabha. Max Strength : 250 (238 elected/12 nominated) Present Strength is 245 – 229 represent States/ 4 represent UTs/ 12 nominated by President. 4th Schedule deals with allocation of seats to UTs & States in Rajya Sabha. Representative of States are elected by elected members of State Leg Assemblies by the System of Proportional Representation by Single Transferable Vote. Seats are allocated to each State on population. Representative of UTs are elected by a Special electoral college based on the system of Proportional Representation by Single Transferable Vote. Only Delhi & Puducherry have representation in Rajya Sabha.
