North-Eastern Council : estb by separate Parl Act – Assam, Manipur, Mizoram, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Meghalaya, Tripura, Sikkim.

Constitution has divided all Legislative, Executive & Financial Powers between the Centre & States. No Division of Judicial Powers as Judiciary is integrated. Centre-State Relations can be studied under three heads : Legislative Relations. Administrative Relations. Financial Relations. Legislative Relations Legislative Relations – Part XI — Art 245 to 255. Territorial extent of Central & State Legislation. Distribution of Legislative Subjects. Parliamentary Legislation in the state field. Centre’s control over State legislation. Territorial extent of Central & State Legislation. Parliament can make laws for whole ‘territory of India’ – including states, UTs. State Leg can make laws for entire state. Law only applicable within state. Parliament alone can make ‘extra-territorial legislation’ – laws applying to all Indian citizens & their properties in any part of the world. Restrictions on Territorial jurisdiction of Parliament : Prez may make regulations, which will have force of law, for the peace, progress & good governance of 4 UTs – Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep, Dadra & Nagar Haveli, Daman & Diu. Prez may also repeal or amend any act of Parl in relation to these 4 UTs. Gov can rule any act of Parl as inapplicable to a Scheduled Area in the state. Gov can also allow the law’s application with certain specific modifications or exceptions. Gov of Assam can rule any Act of Parl as partly or wholly inapplicable to a tribal area in Assam. Prez can do same in Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram. Distribution of Legislative Subjects. Three fold distribution of Legislative Subjects : Union List — Only Parliament can make laws – 100 subjects includes defence, banking, foreign affairs, etc. State List — Only State Leg can make laws – 61 Subjects – public order, police, health, agriculture, etc. Concurrent list — Both Parl & State Leg can make laws – 52 subjects – criminal law, civil law, electricity, etc. Residuary powers are vested in the Parliament. (Canada model) Borrowed from Govt of India Act, 1935. Predominance of Union list over State & Concurrent Lists, & of Concurrent list over State List. Union law always prevails over a State law made on the same Concurrent subject, except when that State law was originally reserved by Gov for consideration of Prez who gave consent to it. Parliamentary legislation in the State Field. Parliament can make laws on any Subject in State list in certain cases : When Rajya Sabha passes a resolution : declaring that subject of National Importance. Such resolution passed by ⅔ of members present & voting, remains active for 1 year & must be renewed after 1 year any no. of times. Law’s effect ends 6 months from expiry of resolution. State leg also has powers to simultaneously make laws on this subject but Union law prevails. During a National Emergency : Law’s effect ends 6 months from expiry of emergency. State can make laws simultaneously but Union law prevails. When States make a request : two or more States pass resolution to request. Laws only applicable in such States which make request. State cannot make simultaneous laws. Such law can only be amended or repealed by Parl. To implement International Agreements. During President’s Rule : Such law continues to be have effect until repealed or amended by the State Legislature after the President’s Rule. Centre’s Control over State Legislation. Governor can reserve certain bills for consideration of Prez. Bills on certain matters require prior permission of Prez before introduction in State leg. Eg – Bills restricting freedom of trade or commerce. During Financial Emergency, Prez can direct State leg to reserve money bills & other finance bills for his consideration. Such control granted mainly to protect the Unity and integrity of India & to maintain administrative stability during emergencies. Administrative Relations Administrative Relations – Part XI — Art 256 to 263. Distribution of Executive Powers. Obligation of States & Centre. Centre’s directions to the States. Mutual delegation of Functions. Cooperation between the Centre & States. All-India Services. Public Service Commissions. Integrated Judicial System. Relations during Emergencies. Other Provisions. Extra-Constitutional Devices. Distribution of Executive Powers. Centre’s powers – Extends to whole of Territory of India. All matters in the Union List. Powers to excercise rights, authority & jurisdiction conferred on it by a treaty or an agreement. States’ powers extend to their own respective territories. States have powers on all matters in the State List. States also have exclusive powers on all matters in the Concurrent List unless specified otherwise by a Constituonal Provision or a Parliamentary Law. A law enacted on a Concurrent subject by the Parliament is to be executed, by default, by the States. Obligation of States & the Centre. Constitution places two restrictions on the exec powers of the States. It is obligation of State to to exercise exec power in such a way : As to ensure compliance with Parliamentary Laws & all other laws which apply in the State. As not to impede or prejudice the exercise of exec powers of the Centre in the States, including the executive power of the Centre to give directions to the State to enforce the two obligations. If a State fails to comply with either of these obligations, Art 365 can be used to impose President’s Rule. Centre’s Directions to the States. Centre has power to give directions to the States in following matters : To enforce the two Constitutional obligations of the State in exercising their executive power. Construction & maintainance of means of communication, which is of national or military importance, by the State. Measures to be taken for the protection of railways in the state. Provision of adequate facilities for instruction in mother-tongue at primary stage of education to children of linguistic minorities. Drawing up & execution of specified schemes for the welfare of Scheduled Tribes in the State. Mutual Delegation of Functions. President may, with consent of the concerned state Govt, entrust an executive power of the Centre to that State. Governor may entrust a State’s executive power to the Centre with the the latter’s consent. This entrustment of exec power may be conditional or unconditional. Parliament may by law also entrust an executive function on to the State, even without the consent of the State. Cooperation between the Centre & States. Constitutional Provisions to secure cooperation & coordination between Centre & States : Parliament can provide for adjudication of dispute in relation to use, distribution & control of any inter-state river or river valley. Under Art 263 – President can estb an Inter-State Council to discuss subject of common interest between Centre & States. All public acts, records & judicial proceedings of the Centre & every State are given full faith & credit throuout the Territory of India. Parliament can appoint an authority to enforce the constituonal provisions relating to inter-state freedom of trade, commerce & intercourse. All-India Services. Three All-India Services : Indian Administrative Service (IAS). Indian Police Service (IPS). Indian Forest Service (IFS). Recruited & Trained by Centre. Eligible to work under both State & Central Govts. Ultimate control of the services with Centre, immediate control with States. Art 312 – Authorises Parliament to create new All-India Services after a resolution by the Rajya Sabha to that effect. Applicability of Services : Maintain high standard of administration throughout the country. Maintain uniformity of administrative system throughout India. Facilitate cooperation & Joint action between Centre & States. Public Service Commissions. In field of Public Service Commissions, Centre-State Relations are : Governor can appoint Chairman & members of SPSC, but they can only be removed by the President. Parliament can create Joint SPSCs for two or more States on the request of State legislatures concerned. President appoints the members of this JSPSC. UPSC can serve the needs of State on the request of the State Governor with the approval of the President. UPSC assists, when requested by two or mare concerned States, with framing & operation of schemes for joint recruitment for any services requiring special qualifications for the candidates. Integrated Judicial System. Single System of Courts. Supreme Court is the Head. All courts can enforce Central as well as State Laws. Judges of HC are appointed by Prez in consultation with CJI & Governor of State. HC judges can be transferred & removed by the President. Parliament has power to establish a common HC for two or more States. – Maharashtra & Goa, Punjab & Haryana. Relations during Emergencies. Art 352 (National Emergency) – Centre can give executive directions to States on any matter. Art 356 (President’s Rule) – President can assume all executive powers of the State Govt, Governor & all other executive authorities. Art 360 (Financial Emergency) – States can be instructed to seek prior permission of Prez before expenditure & follow all other instructions of the Prez. Prez can also reduce salaries of State Govt employees & HC judges. Other Provisions. Other Constitutional Provisions for the Centre to exercise control over States : Art 355 – imposes two duties on Centre : (a) to protect every State against external aggression & internal disturbance. (b) to ensure State Govts comply with Constitution. Governor appointed & removed by President. Gov acts as an agent of Centre submitting periodical admin reports of the State to Prez. State Election Commissioner, though appointed by Governor, can only be removed by the Prez. Extra-Constitutional Devices. Extra-Constitutional Devices to promote cooperation & coordination between Centre & States include advisory bodies & conferences. Non-Constitutional Advisory Bodies : NITI Aayog/National Development Council/National Integration Council/Central Council of Health/Central Council of Local Govt & Urban Development/Zonal Councils/North-Eastern Council/Central Council of Indian Medicine/Central Council of Homeopathy/Central Family Welfare Council/Transport Development Council/University Grants Commission, etc. Conferences : Governors’ Conference (presided by Prez) /Chief Ministers’ Conference (presided by PM) /Chief Secretaries’ Conference (presided by Cabinet Secretary) /Conference of Inspector-General of Police/Chief Justices’ Conference (presided by CJI) /Conference of Vice Chancellors/Home Ministers’ Conference (presided by Union Home Minister) /Law Ministers’ Conference (presided by Union Law Minister). Financial Relations. Financial Relations – Part XIl — Art 268 to 293. Allocation of Taxing Powers. Distribution of Tax revenues. Distribution of Non-tax Revenues. Grants-in-Aid to the States. Finance Commission. Protection of States’ interest. Borrowing by the Centre & the States. Inter-Governmental Tax Immunities. Effects of Emergencies. Allocation of Taxing Powers. Division of Taxing Powers : Parliament can levy tax on subjects in Union List (15 subjects in total). State Legislatures can levy tax on subjects in State List (20 subjects). Parl & State leg can levy tax on Concurrent subjects (3 subjects). Residuary taxation powers lie with the Parliament. Restrictions on States’ Taxing Powers : Tax on professions, trades, callings, employment cannot exceed Rs 2500 per person per annum. Restrictions on Sales tax : if the sale or purchase is outside the State/no tax in the course of import or export/no tax in the course of inter-state trade & commerce/on goods declared so by Parl. No tax on electricity : consumed or sold to Centre/consumed in construction or maintenance or operation of any railway. Prez’s assent needed for water/electricity tax on inter-state river auth. Distribution of Tax Revenues. (Art 268) Taxes levied by Centre but collected & appropriated by States : Stamp duties on bills of exchange, cheques, insurance policies, etc. Excise duties on medicinal & toilet preps containing alcohol & narcotics. Not a part of Consolidated Fund of India, instead of State. (Art 268-A) Centrally levied Service Tax, collected & appr by Centre & State : Taxes on Services, principles of collection/appr decided by Parliament. (Art 269) Taxes levied & collected by Centre but Assigned to States : Sales Tax on goods (except newspapers) in course of Inter-State trade. Taxes on Consignment of goods in course of Inter-State trade/comm. Not a part of Consolidated Fund of India. Assigned accd to Parliament. (Art 270) Tax levied & collected by Centre, distributed to Centre & States : All matters in Union List except taxes in Art 268/268-A/269/271 & cess levied for specific purpose. Distribution is prescribed by Prez according to Finance Commission. (Art 271) Surcharge on certain taxes & duties for purposes of Centre : Parliament can levy surcharges on taxes in Art 269 & 270. Proceeds go to the Centre. Taxes levied & collected & retained by the States : Matters in State List : land revenue/taxes on agri income, succession & estate duties in respect of agri land/taxes on lands & buildings, on mineral rights, on animals & boats, on road vehicles, on luxuries, on entertainments, on gambling/excise duty on liquor & narcotics/taxes on entry of goods into local area, on advertisements (except newspapers), on consumption or sale of electricity, on goods & passengers carried by road or waterway/taxes on professions, trades, callings, employment not exceeding ₹2500 per annum/capitation taxes/tolls/stamp duty on documents (except those in Union List)/sales tax (other than newspapers)/fees on matters in State List (except court fees). Distribution of Non-tax Revenues. Sources of Non-tax Revenues for the Centre : Posts & telegraphs. Railways. Banking. Broadcasting. Coinage & currency. Central Public Sector Enterprises. Escheat & lapse. Sources of Non-tax Revenues for the States : Irrigation. Forests. Fisheries. State Public Sector Enterprises. Escheat & lapse. Grants-in-Aid to the States. Two types of Grants-in-Aid : Statutory Grants : Article 275 empowers Parl to make grants to States in need of Financial Assistance & not to all States. Different sums to different States according to need. Specific Grants for welfare of Scheduled Tribes & raising administration level in Scheduled areas in all States. Grants are given based on recommendation of the Finance Commission. Discretionary Grants : Art 282 empowers Centre & States to make grants for any public purpose, including those outside legislative competence. No obligation on the Centre & it has complete discretion. Purpose to help financially & to influence State action. Other Grants : Temporary grants for a period of 10 yrs from commencement of Const in lieu of export duties on jute & jute products to Assam, Bihar, Orissa & West Bengal. Not applicable currently. Finance Commission. Article 280 provides for Finance Commission – Quasi-judicial body. Constituted by President every 5 years or earlier to make recommendations: Sharing tax income between Centre & States, & share among States. Principles governing Grants-in-Aid to the States. Measures to augment Cons Fund if State to supplement resources of Panchayats & Municipalities according to recommendations of the State Finance Commission. Other matters referred to it by Prez regarding financial matters. Finance Commission acts as the balancing wheel of fiscal federalism. Its role has been undermined by the Planning Commission, & now by the NITI Aayog. Protection of the State’s Interests. To protect State’s Interests, following bills can only be introduced in Parliament on recommendation of the President : Bill which varies any tax or duty in which states are interested. Bill changing meaning of ‘agricultural income’ as defined for Indian income tax. Bill which affects the principles of sharing money with the states. Bill imposing surcharge on any tax or duty for the purposes of Centre. Borrowing by the Centre & States. Following Constitutional provisions for borrowing by Centre & States : Centre can borrow within or outside India upon the security of Consolidated Fund of India, within limits set by Parliament. State Govts can borrow with India only upon security of Consolidated Fund of State, within limits fixed by State Legislature. Central Govt can make loans to States or give guarantees on loans raised by states from the Consolidated Fund of India. If there is outstanding of any part of loan made to the state by Centre or on a loan guaranteed by the Centre, then that State Govt must take prior permission of the Centre before raising fresh loans. Inter-Governmental Tax Immunities. Provisions regarding ‘immunity from mutual taxation’ : Exemption Central Property from State Taxation : Properties of Centre in States are exempted from all taxes except when specified by the Parliament. Properties include movable & immovable but not companies or Corps. Exemption of State Property or Income from Central Taxation : Property & income of State is exempted from central taxation. Commercial operations can be taxed if Parliament provides. Parliament can also exempt any State trade or business. Property & income of local authority within the state are not exempted. State companies & corporations are also not exempted. Centre can impose customs duty on goods imported or exported by State or impose Excise duty on goods manufactures by state. Effects of Emergencies. National Emergency (Art 352) : President can modify the Constitutional distribution of revenues between Centre & States. President can either reduce or cancel entirely the transfer of finances. Such modification will have effect until the end of the financial year. Financial Emergency (Art 360) : Centre can direct to observe the specified canons of financial propriety. Direct to reduce salaries & allowances of all class of employees & HC judges. Direct to reserve all money bills & finance bills for the consideration of the President. Trends & Developments. Tension Areas in Centre-State Relations. Post 1967, Non-Congress States demanded more autonomy. Several issues of tensions & conflicts arose : Mode of appointment & removal of Governor. Discriminatory & partisan role of Governors. Imposition of President’s Rule for partisan interests. Deployment of Central forces in States to maintain law & order. Reservation of State bills for consideration of President. Discrimination in financial allocation to the States. Role of Planning Commission in approving State Projects. Management of All-India Services (IAS, IPS, IFS). Use of electronic media for political purposes. Appointment of enquiry Commissions against chief ministers. Sharing of finances between Centre & States. Encroachment by Centre on the State List. Developments in Centre State Relations. Administrate Reforms Commission recommendations : 1966 Establishment of Inter-State Council (under Art 263) /appointing non-partisan Governors with admin experience/Delegate powers to States/ Transfer financial resources to States/deploy Central Armed Frc on request. No action taken on any of the recommendation. Rajamannar Committee recommendations : 1969 by Tamil Nadu Govt. Estb Inter-State Council/ Make Finance Commission permanent body/ Abolish Planning Commission/ Abolish President’s Rule/Transfer certain subjects of Union & Concurrent list to States/ Give States Residuary Power/Abolish All-India Services. — no recommendations accepted. Anandpur Sahib Resolution : 1973 by Akali Dal. Demanded restriction of Centre’s jurisdiction to defence, foreign affairs, communications & currency/ Give States Residuary Powers /Estb true Federation with equal representation of States in Centre. West Bengal Memorandum : 1977 by West Bengal Govt. Replace word ‘Union’ with ‘federal’/ reduce Union jurisdiction/ President’s Rule & Financial Emergency should be repealed /75% revenue should go to States/increase Rajya Sabha powers/Abolish All-India Services/ etc. Sarkaria Commission : 1983 by Central Govt. Did not favour structural changes, instead wanted operational changes/ Estb Inter-State Council/ Use President’s Rule as last resort/ Strengthen All-India Services/ except taxation, all Residuary Powers should be in Concurrent list/Reasons for President withholding State Bills should be communicated /zonal councils should be refreshed/Consulting CM of State for appointing Gov should be Constitutionalised/ Gov cannot dismiss CoM so long as they have majority/Commission of Enquiry only after demand by Parliament/Commissioner for linguistic minorities should be activated. — 180 out of 247 total recommendations were accepted. Inter-State Council established in 1990. Punchhi Commission : 2007 by Govt of India. Reach agreement with States before introducing Concurrent Bill in Parl /Upper hand of States in State & Concurrent matters/6 month limit for President’s consideration on reserved bill/Gov should be no-domicile eminent person not active politically recently – 5yr fixed tenure with impeachment possiblity like Prez/ Gov gets 6 months to reserve or assent bill/ Fixed guidelines for appointing CM in hung assembly/President’s Rule under Art 356 should be last resort/fixed guidelines for defining ‘breakdown of Constitutional Machinery’/Usage of localised emergencies in States over President’s Rules/further empower Inter-State Council to solve Centre-State disputes/New All-India Services in health, edu, engineering, Judiciary/ empower Rajya Sabha as a repr forum of States/Equal seats to each State despite population/Scope of devolution of Powers to local governments should be Constitutionally defined/Cost sharing for implementation of Central laws/Abolish Profession tax ceiling/other measures for fiscal fairness — Still being considered by Inter-State Council.

Introduction. Federal System – Powers of Central & Regional Govts are given by the Constitution. Unitary Govt – Only Central Govt powers are given by the Constitution. All other Govts derive their powers as dictated by the Central Govt. India is a ‘Union of States’ with a Stronger Centre. (Canada model) Term ‘Federation’ not mentioned in the Constitution. Federal System was adopted due to the large size of the Country & Socio-cultural diversity. Indian Constitution provides for a mix of Federal & Unitary features. Federal Features of the Constitution. Dual Polity : Separate independent Govts at Centre & States. Written Constitution : Powers of Centre & States clearly marked out in the form a written book. Division of Powers : Powers divided into Union (100 subjects) , State (61 subjects) & Concurrent (52 subjects) Lists. Supremacy of Constitution : All organs of Govt at Centre & States operate within jurisdiction provided by Const. Centre can’t step over States. Rigid Constitution : Provisions regarding Federal Structure of Country are difficult to amend, requiring Special Majority + Consent of States. Independent Judiciary : To protect & enforce Supremacy of Constitution. Bicameralism : Rajya Sabha is a permanent representation of States. Unitary Features of the Constitution. Strong Centre : Union List has more subjects, with more important subjects & overriding authority over Concurrent list. Residuary Powers lies with Centre. States Not Indestructible : Parliament can unilaterally, by simple majority, change the area, boundary & names of any State. Single Constitution : No separate Constitution for States (except J&K). Flexibility of the Constitution : Most provisions can be amended unilaterally by the Parliament through Simple or Special Majority. Emergency Provisions : During emergency, Centre becomes all powerful and the country functions as a Unitary structure. Single Citizenship : No Second Citizenship for domicile of States. Integrated Judiciary : Single system of Courts enforces both Central & State Laws. All-India Services : Officers recruited by Centre to work in States. Integrated Audit Machinery : Comptroller & Auditor-General of India is appointed by President but has powers to audit the accounts of both Centre & States. Parliament’s Authority over State Lists : Parl. can make laws on any Subject of the State List if Rajya Sabha passes a resolution in favour of doing so. Appointment of Governor : Appointed by President. Acts as an agent of Centre. Integrated Election Machinery : Members appointed by President. Conduct elections for entire country at Central & State levels. Veto over State Bills : Governor has right to reserve certain bills passed by State Legislature for the consideration of the President. The President can outright reject any such bill.

Introduction. Constitution provides for a Parliamentary form of Govt at Centre & States. Art 74 & 75 – deal with Central Parliamentary System. Art 163 & 164 – deal with States’ Parliamentary System. In opposition to Presidential form – executive not responsible to legislature. Parliamentary form – executive is directly responsible to the legislature. Borrowed from Britain – Westminster Model of Govt. Features of Parliamentary Government. Nominal & Real Executives : President is only nominal exec with the PM & Council of Ministers as Real Exec. Advice of CoM is binding on President. Majority Party Rule : Politics Party with majority in Lok Sabha forms Govt & Prez appoints its leader as PM. Other ministers are appointed by Prez on binding advice of PM. However, Prez has discretion to choose anyone as PM. Collective Responsibility : CoM are collectively responsible to the Parliament in general & Lok Sabha in particular (Art 75). Lok Sabha can dismiss entire Ministry by passing Vote of No Confidence. Political Homogeneity : CoM share same political ideology belonging to same political party or are bound by consensus in coalition. Double Membership : CoM hold membership leg & exec. Any Minister who is not an MP for a period longer than 6 months ceases to be a minister. Leadership of the PM : PM is leader of CoM, Parliament & Majority Party. Dissolution of the Lower House : Exec enjoys right to dissolve leg. Prez dissolves leg on advice of PM before elections. Secrecy : Ministers cannot divulge info on CoM proceedings, policies & decisions. Prez administers the oath of secrecy. Features of Presidential Government. Prez is both head of State & of Govt (Real executive). No nominal executive. Prez cannot be removed by legislature, except through impeachment proceedings. President’s Cabinet is only an advisory body. Their advise is not binding. Prez & his Secretaries (members of cabinet) are not responsible to the legislature and are not members of the Legislature. Secretaries are nominated on complete discretion by the President. President cannot dissolve the lower House. All three wings of Govt – legislature, executive & Judiciary – are separated from each other and function independently. Merits of Parliamentary System. Harmony between Leg & Exec : Less scope for disputes as exec are part of leg. Responsible Govt : Representatives of People (MPs) are directly able to check the Govt. Prevents despotism : Exec is directly responsible to Parliament & can be dismissed by them. Ready Alternative Govt : When ruling party loses majority, opposition can be invited to form Govt, hence a fresh election need not be held. Wide Representation : Ministers are representatives of different constituencies from different parts of India, therefore allowing wide representation of opinions from representatives from different places. Demerits of Parliamentary System. Unstable Govt : Govts have no guarantee of tenure and are at the mercy of party legislators in majority. A no-confidence motion or political defection or evils of multiparty system could bring the Govt down. No Continuity of Policies : Policies change with Govts, with unstable Govts policy changes can be far too frequent within short periods of time. Dictatorship of Cabinet : When ruling party has absolute majority, its leaders in Cabinet become dictatorial & autocratic. Against Separation of Powers : Cabinet acts as leader of leg & Exec, allowing no checks & balances on their powers. Govt by Amateurs : PM limited to appointment of Ministers from either houses of Parliament. No non-political expert can be appointed. Reasons for Adopting Parliamentary System Familiarity with System before independence. Constituent Assembly gave preference to a Responsible Govt. Need to avoid Leg-Exec disputes. Diversity of India required wider representation in Govt. Distinction between Indian & British Models of Govt India has Republican system instead of a Monarchy. Parliament is not sovereign as we have India has Written Constitution. In India PM can be member of either House of Parl. British PM can only be from the Lower House. Indian Ministers can be appointed for a max period of six months even if they are not MPs. British Ministers are always MPs. Indian ministers do not countersign the orders of the Head of State (Prez). British Ministers countersign orders of the monarch. British Parl has ‘Shadow Cabinet’ formed of Members of Opposition. India has no Shadow Cabinet.

Introduction. ‘Basic Structure Doctrine’ is not a part of the Constitution. Created by the Supreme Court in the Kesavananda Bahrati v. State of Kerela (1973). Only applicable to Constitutional Amendments (after 1973). This Judicial Principle declares that certain basic features of the Constitution cannot be altered or destroyed even through Constitutional Amendments. The contents of Basic Structure not defined explicitly by SC. Contents established over many years through various judgments. Elements of the Basic Structure. Supremacy of the Constitution. Sovereign, democratic & republican nature of the Indian Polity. Secular Character of the Constitution. Separation of Powers between the Leg, exec & Judiciary. Federal Character of the Constitution. Unity & integrity of the Nation. Welfare State (socio-economic justice). Judicial Review. Freedom & dignity of individual. Parliamentary System. Rule of Law. Harmony & balance between Fund Rts & DPSP. Principle of Equality. Free & fair elections Independence of Judiciary Limited powers of the Parliament to amend Constitution Effective access to justice Principles underlying Fundamental Rights. Powers of SC under Art 32, 136, 141 & 142. Powers of HC under Art 226 & 227. Important cases. Kesavananda Bahrati v. State of Kerela (1973) – Supremacy of Constitution/separation of powers/Republic, democratic/Secular/federal/sovereignty & unity/individual freedom & dignity/welfare state/parliamentary system. Indira Nehru Gandhi v. Raj Narain (1975) – Rule of Law/Equality/Judicial Review/Free & fair elections/Secular. Minerva Mills v. Union of India (1980) – Limited power of Parl to amend Const/harmony & balance between Fund Rts & DPSP.

Introduction. Constitution is Partly Rigid & Partly Flexible. Art 368 of Part XX deals with Amendment. Parliament has sole power to amend by addition, variation or repeal. SC (Keshavnanda Bharti case, 1973) provided for ‘Basic Structure of the Constitution’ – all provisions declared as ‘basic structure’ cannot be amended. Procedure for Amendment through Art 368. Introduction of Bill by any member in either House of Parliament only. Must be passed in each House by a Special Majority – majority of total membership & ⅔ of members voting. No provision for Joint Sitting. If Bill seeks to amend federal provisions, Bill must be Ratified by half of the State Legislatures with a simple majority. President’s assent is obligatory. President cannot return or reject Bill. After assent the Bill becomes an Act & the Constitution stands amended. Types of Amendment. Art 368 only provides for two methods of Amendment – Special Majority of Parliament & Special Majority + Consent of States. Some other Articles provide for amendment through Simple Majority alone. Simple Majority : Outside of Art 368. Requires over 50 % of members present & voting. Provisions include – Admission or Estab of new States/formation of new States, alteration of their boundaries or names/Abolition or creation of Leg Councils/2nd Sch – salary & perks of Prez, Govs, judges, etc./Quorum in Parliament/Salaries & allowances of MPs/Rules of Prc of Parl/Privileges of Parliament/Use of English Language in Parl/Number of puisne Judges in SC/increase of SC jurisdiction/Citizenship acquisition & termination/Elections to Parliament & State Leg/Delimitation of Constituencies/Union Territories/5th Sch – admin of Sch Areas & Tribes/6th Sch – admin of tribal areas. Special Majority : Requires over 50% of total membership of each House & ⅔ of total members present & Voting. Includes Provisions of Fundamental Rights, Directive Principles & All other Provisions not covered under the first & third category. Special Majority + Consent of States : Requires Special Majority of Parliament & ratification by half of the State Legislatures by simple majority. No time limit for the States to give their consent. Includes Provisions of Election of the President & its manner;Extent of exec powers of the Union & States; Supreme Court & High Courts; Distribution of leg powers (Subjects) between Union & States; any lists in 7th Schedule: Representation of States in Parliament; Art 368 itself. Criticism of the Amendment Procedure. No provision for a special body for amendment of Constitution like Constitutional Convention (as in USA). Parliament is all powerful. Power to initiate amendments lies with Parl. (exception in creation/abolition of State Legislative Council – here too Parl can reject the proposal). Major part can be amended by Parl alone without State consent. No time frame for States to ratify Amendments, no clarification if consent given to the amendment can be withdrawn later. No provision for Joint Sitting of both houses of Parliament. Most amendments are passed by Simple Majority. Amendment Procedure is not crystal clear, leave room for judicial intervention.

Introduction. Part-lVA — Article 51A Added through the 42nd Amendment of 1976. Based on the recommendation of Swaran Singh Committee. Inspired from the Constitution of erstwhile USSR. Fundamental Rights & Duties are correlative & inseparable. One more duty added through 86th Amendment Act of 2002. Apply only to Citizens. Non-justiciable. Some are moral duties while others are civic duties. List of Fundamental Duties. Abide by Constitution & respect its ideals & institutions, National Flag & National Anthem. Cherish ideals of National Struggle for freedom. Uphold & protect Sovereignty, unity & integrity of India. Defend Country & render national service when called upon. Promote harmony & brotherhood, & respect women. Value & preserve rich heritage of country’s composite culture. Protect & Improve environment – forests, lake, rivers, wildlife. Care for All living creatures. Develop scientific temper, humanism, spirit of inquiry & reform. Safeguard Public Property & abjure violence. Strive towards excellence in all individual & collective activity. Provide education to child or ward between ages 6 & 14 (86th Amd, 2002). Criticism of Fundamental Duties. Does not include duties to vote, paying tax, family planning, etc. Vague terms with no clear meaning like ‘composite culture’. Non-justiciable. Not necessary to define fundamental duties. Should have been added after Part-lll so as to signify its importance. Significance of Fundamental Duties. Serve as reminder to citizens that Rights go hand in hand with duties. Serve as warning against anti-national & anti-social activities. Source of inspiration to the citizens. A set of ideals to live by. SC ruled in 1992 that any law seeking to give effect to Fundamental Duties may be considered valid & reasonable & cannot be challenged on the basis of violation of Art 14 & Art 19. Enforceable by law made by the Parliament.

Introduction. Enumerated in Part-lV of the Constitution – Article 36-51. Article 36 deals the definition of State in Context of DPSP. Art 37 deals with nature & significance of the DPSP. Borrowed from the Irish Constitution of 1937 which had copied it from the Spanish Constitution. Contain philosophy of the Constitution. Conscience of the Constitution. Contain the goals and ideals that every successive Govt must keep in mind & work towards in day to day functioning & policy-making. Features of the Directive Principles. Art 36 – gives the same definition to ‘State’ as Part-lll. Resemble the ‘Instrument of Instruction’ in Govt of India Act, 1935. Embody concept of Welfare State & not Police State. Seek to establish social & economic democracy in India . Non-justiciable in Nature. Art 37 – declares DPSP fundamental in gov of country & it shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in the making of laws & policies. Helps in determining the Constitutional validity of a law. SC has ruled that if a law seeks to give effect to a Directive Principle, then that law may be considered to be ‘reasonable’ in relation to Art 14 or Art 19. Fundamental Rights enjoy Supremacy however they can be amended in order to implement Directive Principles without affecting the Basic Structure of the Constitution. Classification of the Directive Principles. Socialistic Principles : (lay path towards Welfare State) Art 38 : Promote welfare by securing social order permeated by justice – social, economic & political / minimise inequalities in income, status, facilities & opportunities-44th Amd, 1978. Art 39 : Secure – Right to livelihood/Equal distribution of wealth/prevention of concentration of wealth/Equal pay for equal work for men & women/preserving health of workers & children against forcible abuse/opportunities for healthy development of children – 42nd, 1976. Art 39A : Equal justice & free legal aid for poor – 42nd, 1976. Art 41 : Right to work, education & public assistance. Art 42 : Just, humane working conditions/maternity relief. Art 43 : secure living wage/decent standard of life, social & cultural opps. Art 43A : participation of workers in management – 42nd, 1976. Art 47 : raise level of nutrition, standard of living & public health. Gandhian Principles : (based on Gandhian ideology) Art 40 : Organise Village Panchayats & empower them. Art 43 : Promote cottage indust. on individual or Co-op basis. Art 43B : to promote & empower Cooperative Societies – 97th, 2011. Art 46 : Promote Edu & econ interests of SCs, STs & weaker sections. Art 47 : prohibit consumption of intoxicating drinks & drugs. Art 48 : Prohibit slaughter of cows, calves & milch & Improve breed. Liberal-intellectual Principles : (represents ideology of liberalism) Art 44 : Uniform Civil Code. Art 45 : early childhood care & Edu until 6 yrs of age – 86th, 2002. Art 48 : Organise agriculture & animal husbandry on scientific lines. Art 48A : protect & Improve env, safeguard forests & wildlife – 42nd, ‘76. Art 49 : protect hist monuments, places, objects of art or national imp. Art 50 : separate judiciary from exec in public services of States. Art 51 : Promote intl peace, security. Just & honourable relations between nations,respect intl law & treaty, arbitration for intl disputes. Criticism of the Directive Principles. No Legal Force : a cheque on a bank, payable only when the resources of the bank permit. Can be completely ignored by Govt. Illogically arranged : no classification, no consistency with the more unimportant principles mixed up with the important & fund. principles. Conservative : based on 19th century philosophy. Not suitable for the 21st century challenges & issues. Constitutional Conflict : (a) Centre & States – Centre can give order to States to implement DPSP, & can dismiss state govt if they fail to comply. (b) President & Prime Minister – President may reject bills passed by Parliament on the excuse that it violates DPSP. (c) Governor & States – Governor may also reject bill passed by State Govt if they violate DPSP. Directive Principles outside of Part-lV. Art 335 in Part XVl – Claims of SCs & STs in making of appointments to services & posts to the Union or States. Art 350A in Part XVll – Instruction in mother tongue at primary stage of education to children belonging to linguistic minorities. Art 351 in Part XVll – Duty of Union to promote the spread of Hindi Language Above Principles are Non-justiciable.

Introduction. Part-lll — Article 12-35. Inspired by Constitution of USA (Bill of Rights). Fundamental Rights are justiciable. Guaranteed by the Constitution to all. Supreme Court is the Guardian. 6 Fundamental Rights : Right to Equality (Art 14-18) Right to Freedom (Art 19-22) Right against Exploitation (Art 23-24) Right to Freedom of Religion (Art 25-28) Cultural and Educational Rights (Art 29-30) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Art 31) *Right to Property was deleted by 44th Amd Act and made a legal right under Art 300-A in Part-Xll. Features of Fundamental Rights. Some available only to citizens while others available to all. Not absolute. Bound by Reasonable Restrictions. Most are available against the State, some are available against individuals. Some are negative while others are positive. Justiciable. When violated courts can be approached. Supreme Court can directly be approached without going through HC. Can be curtailed by Parliament. Can be suspended during a National Emergency (except Art 20-21). Art 19 can be suspended only on grounds of war & external aggression. Scope is limited by Article 31A, 31B, 31C. Their application to members of Armed forces, intelligence agencies, police, etc can be restricted or abrogated by Parliament (Art 33). Can be restricted if Martial Law is in place (Article 34). Some of them are direclty enforceable, others need laws for enforcement. Definition of State Art 12 defines the term ‘State’ for the purposes of Part-lll. ‘State’ includes exec & leg at Centre & States/all local authorities/all other statutory & non-statutory authorities like LIC, ONGC, SAIL, etc. SC declared private bodies working as instruments of State in Art 12. Laws Inconsistent with Fundamental Rights Art 13 all laws inconsistent with fund rights shall be void. Provides for Judicial Review to protect FR. (SC – Art 32/HC – Art 226) The term ‘law’ has been defined in Art 13 where it includes all laws of all legislatures, all Ordinances of the exec, all delegated legislation by exec & exec orders, non-legislative sources of law like custom which has force of law. Art 13 also declares Const Amnd cannot be challenged as they are not laws, but SC overruled this – Const Amnd cannot violate basic structure. Armed Forces & Fundamental Rights Art 33 empowers Parliament (not State leg) to curtail FR of members of Armed forces, para-military forces, police forces, intelligence agencies & analogous forces. Accordingly Army Act, Navy Act & Air Force Act (1950), Police Forces (Restriction of Rights) Act, 1966 & others have been enacted. Court Martials are also excluded from Judicial Review in FR cases. Martial Law & Fundamental Rights Art 34 implicitly authorises exec to declare martial law. The term ‘martial law’ has not been used and no explicit powers given. Borrowed from English Common Law. Military authorities are vested with abnormal powers to restrict FR. SC declared Martial Law does not ipso facto lead to suspension of writs. Martial Law is declared in specific area of country or State. Exceptions to Fundamental Rights. Saving of Laws Providing for Acquisition of Estates, etc. : Art 31A declares 5 category of laws immune from invalidation in violation of Art 14 & Art 19 : acquisition of Estates, State management of properties, amalgamation of Corporations, rights of shareholders & directors of Corporations, modification of mining leases. Provides for payment of compensation on market values. Validation of Certain Rights & Regulations : Art 31B gives immunity to laws placed in 9th Schedule. In I. R. Coelho case (2007), SC declared laws 9th Sch laws violating FR under Art 14, 15, 19, 21 & Basic Structure can be challenged. Saving of Laws giving effect to certain DPSP : Art 31C declares laws made to achieve DPSP under Art 39(b) & 39(c) (equal distribution of wealth) cannot be challenged in violation of Art 14 & 19. Right To Equality. Introduction. Article 14-18. Article 14 – Equality before Law & Equal protection of laws. Article 15 – Prohibition of discrimination on the grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth. Article 16 – Equality of Opportunity in matters of Public Employment. Article 17 – Abolition of Untouchability & prohibition of its practice. Article 18 – Abolition of titles except military & academic. Equality before Law & Equal protection of laws. Art 14 guarantees equality before Law & Equal protection of laws for all (including foreigners, Corporations, organisations, societies, etc). Equality before Law : Absence of special privileges/Equal subjection of all to law/No person is above the Law. — is of British Origin. Equal protection of Law : Equal treatment under equal circumstances/ similar application of laws on people similarly situated/like treated alike. Based on Rule of Law – Art 14 is part of Basic Structure of Constitution. Exceptions to Equality : Art 361 – Prez & Gov – enjoy immunity for all exec actions / no criminal cases or arrest during office / 2 months notice before private civil case. Art 361A – media publication of true report of Leg proceedings. Art 105 & 194 – immunity to MPs & MLA/MLC for speech/vote in Leg. Art 31C – Art 14 not app to laws made under Art 39(b)&(c). Foreign and UN diplomats have diplomatic immunity. Prohibition of Discrimination on Certain Grounds. Art 15 bans discrimination only on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth. – discrimination on other grounds is not prohibited. Prohibits subjection to any disability, liability, restriction or condition on same grounds from – access to shops, restaurants, hotels & places of public entertainment / use of wells, tanks, etc maintained or constructed by State. Exceptions : permits Special provision for Women, children, SC, ST, OBC. 93rd Amendment introduced 27% OBC qouta. SC directed Centre to exclude Creamy Layer from the OBC category. Creamy Layer : Children of persons —holding Constitutional Positions – Prez, VP, Judges, etc. ; Group A /Class I & Group B/Class ll Officers of All India, Central & State Services, equivalent positions in PSUs, Banks, Univs, etc. ; Ranking in or above Colonel and equivalent posts in Armed Forces; Professionals like doctors, lawyers, engineers, etc; holding properties above a certain limit; with Gross annual income of 6 lacs and above. Equality of Opportunity in Public Employment. Provided in Art 16 without discrimination of religion, caste, race, sex, etc. Exceptions : Parliament can prescribe residence as condition/reservation for backward classes/reservation of religious office for members of the religion. Mandal Commission & Aftermath : Second Backward Classes Commission under chairmanship of B. P. Mandal was set up in 1979. 1990 – 27% OBC quota made. 1991 – economic criteria adopted for OBC quota & 10% quota for economically weaker High Castes made. 1992 – in Mandal Case, SC 10% poor high caste quota / directed creamy layer to be removed / banned reservation in promotion / 50% quota limit set / ‘carry forward rule’ for backlog vacancies limited to 50% / directed for Permanent Statutory body to examine complaints. 1993 – National Commission for Backward Classes estb. 1995 – 77th Amendment allowed reservations in promotion. 2000 – 81st Amd nullified backlog vacancy ruling. Abolition of Untouchability. Art 17 bans Untouchability; punishable by Law. Untouchability (offences) Act, 1955 amemended & renamed in 1976 as Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955 : The Act (nor the Constitution) define the term ‘Untouchability’. Offencers a n be punished by imprisonment upto 6 months or by fine upto ₹500 or both. Offences : preventing person from place of worship / justifying Untouchability / denying access to shops, hotels, etc/ insulting member of SC on grounds of Untouchability/ refusing admission to hospitals, educational institutions or hostel estb for public benefit / preaching Untouchability / refusing to sell good & services. SC held Art 17 is available against individuals. Abolition of Titles. Art 18 abolishes titles & makes four provisions : Prohibits State from conferring titles (except military & academic). Citizens prohibited from accepting titles from any foreign State. Foreigner holding Office of Profit under Govt must take President’s permission before accepting any titles from a foreign State. Prohibits Citizens & foreigners holding any office of profit under Govt to accept any presents, emoluments or office from foreign State without President’s permission. SC declared National Awards like Bharat Ratna & Padma awards to be valid as they are not ‘titles’, but banned their usage as suffixes or prefixes to the names of the awardees. Right to Freedom . Introduction. Article 19-22. Art 19 – Protection of Six Rights : speech & expression/ Assembly / Association / Movement / Residence / Profession. Art 20 – Protection in respect of conviction for offences. Art 21 – Protection of life & liberty. Art 21A – Right to Elementary Education. Art 22 – Protection against arrest & detention in certain cases. Protection of Six Rights. Art 19 guarantees Six rights. Originally contained a 7th right to acquire, hold & dispose of property, which was deleted by 44th Amd of 1978. Available only for Citizens against State only, not against individuals. Can only be restricted by Reasonable Restrictions as mentioned in Art 19. Freedom of Speech & Expression : Includes Right to express views/ Freedom of press/Freedom of commercial adverts/Right against tapping of telephonic conversation/to telecast/against bundh/to know about Govt activities/Freedom of silence/against pre-censorship of newspaper/to demonstrate or picketing but not to strike. State can impose reasonable restrictions on speech & expression on the grounds of protecting sovereignty & integrity of India, security of State, friendly relations with foreign states, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, & incitement to an offence. Freedom of Assembly : Right to assemble peacefully without arms. Right to public meetings, demonstrations & to take out processions. State can impose reasonable restrictions to protect sovereignty & integrity & public order including maintenance of traffic. Section 144 of CrPC can restrain assembly, meeting or procession on risk of danger to human life, riot, obstruction or any affray. Section 141 of IPC restricts assembly of 5 or more people if object is to resist execution of law; forcibly occupy property of some person; to commit any mischief or criminal trespass; to force some person to do illegal act; to threaten Govt officials for exercising lawful powers. Freedom of Association : Right to form unions, associations or Co-ops. Right not to join or form associations or organisations. Can be restricted to protect sovereignty, integrity, pub order, morality. Right to obtain recognition of association is not a Fundamental Right. Freedom of Movement : Right to move freely in territory of India. 2 grounds of restriction – to protect interests of general public & ST. SC validated restriction on grounds of Public Health. Freedom of Residence : Right to reside or settle in any part of country. Same grounds of restriction as Freedom of Movement. Freedom of Profession : Right to practice any Profession or occupation, trade, business, etc. Restrictions in interest of General Public. State empowered to prescribe a professional or technical qualification for practicing any profession. State has power to restrict private participation in a field of business. The Right does not include doing a profession which is immoral or dangerous. Protection in Respect of Conviction for Offences. Art 20 protects all against arbitrary arrest & excessive punishment. No ex-post-facto law : Conviction & punishment only in accordance to law in force at the time of commitment of criminal offence. No double jeopardy : prosecution & punishment only once for offence. No self-incrimination : no compulsion to be witness against self. Ex-post-facto not applicable to Civil laws or tax laws. Protection against double jeopardy is only in Court of Laws or Judicial tribunal, but not before departmental or admin authorities. Protection against self-incrimination only includes oral or documentary evidence. It does no extend to compulsory production of material objects, compulsion to give thumb impression, specimen signature, blood specimens, etc, cumpolsory exhibition of the body. Protection against self-incrimination only available in Criminal cases and not civil cases. Protection of Life & Liberty. Art 21 – no person shall be deprived of personal life or liberty except through procedure established by law. Gopalan Case (1950)- SC held Art 21 only against arbitrary exec action & not against leg. So laws made by leg could arbitrarily deprive life & liberty. Menaka Case (1978)- SC ruled that laws must be reasonable, just & fair. Art 21 includes Right to – Live with human dignity/decent environment/livelihood/privacy/shelter/health/free edu upto 14/free legal aid/agn solitary confinement/speedy trial/agn handcuffing/agn inhuman treatment/agn delayed execution/travel abroad/agn bonded labour/agn custodial harassment/Emergency medical aid/timely treatment in Govt hospital/agn being driven out of State/fair trail/prisoner to have necessities of life/women be treated with decency & dignity/agn public hanging/hearing/info/reputation/appeal/sleep/electricity/social security & protection of family/agn bar fetters/agn noise pollution/life insurance/soc-econ justice. Right to Education. Art 21A – Free & compulsory education to all between 6 to 14 years. Added through 86th Amd, 2002, only provides Right to Elementary Edu. Amended Art 45 DPSP to ‘providing early childhood care’ from Edu. Added Art 51A – Fund Duty to provide Edu between 6 to 14 years. SC in 1993 provided for Right to Elementary Edu under Art 21 overruling its judgement of 1992 which gave Right to Edu upto all levels, including Univ. In pursuance of 21A, Parliament enacted Right of Children to Free & Compulsory Education (RTE) Act, 2009 – provides for the legal enactment of Art 21A & detailed guidelines to implement the provisions of 21A. Protection against Arrest and Detention. Art 22 – grants protection to persons who are detained or arrested. Detention is of two types – Punitive detention (punishment after crime by court through trial) & Preventive Detention (detention before crime) First part of Art 22 deals cases of ordinary arrests (non-preventive) : Arrested person has Right to be informed on grounds of arrest/to consult & be defended by a lawyer/to be released after 24 hrs unless magistrate specifies for extention of arrest. Not applicable to enemy Aliens, Preventive Detention cases, arrest under court orders, civil arrest, income tax case, alien deportation case. Second Part provides protection in Preventive Detention arrests : Detention cannot exceed 3 months unless an advisory board (consisting of HC judges) specifies so in its report. Grounds of detention have to be told to detained person except if doing so would be against public interest. Detenu must be allowed to make representation against detention. Art 22 authorises Parliament to prescribe classes of cases in which detention can be over 3 months without advisory board opinion/maximum period of detention for different classes of case/procedure followed by advisory board in an inquiry. 44th Amd, 1978 reduced max detention without advisory board opinion to 2 months from 3 but this has not been enforced. The Union List of leg subjects includes laws of Preventive Detention for reasons connected with defence, foreign affairs & security of India while Concurrent list includes for security of a state, maintenance of public order & maintenance of supplies & services essential to the community. India only Democratic country with Preventive Detention integral to the Constitution. Preventive Detention has high potential to be misused. Right Against Exploitation. Article 23-24. Art 23 – Prohibition of traffic in human beings & forced labour. Art 24 – Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc. Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings & Forced Labour. Art 23 prohibits human trafficking, begar & other forms of forced labour. Offence punishable in accordance to law. Right available to All against State & private Individuals & organisations. Human Trafficking includes : Selling – buying of men, women, children/immoral traffic in women & children, prostitution/devadasis/slavery. Begar – work without pay. Forced or Bonded Labour – includes physically forced labour & force arising from compulsion of economic circumstances. Laws enacted by Parliament – Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956 / Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act, 1976/ Minimum Wages Act, 1948/Contract Labour Act, 1970/ Equal Remuneration Act, 1976. Art 23 exception – State can impose compulsory military or social service. Prohibition of Employment of Children in Factories, etc. Art 24 – prohibits employment of children below 14 years in factories, mines, or other hazardous activities like construction work or Railways. Does not prohibit employment in a non-hazardous work. SC in 1996 directed establishment of Child Labour Rehabilitation Welfare Fund – Offender deposits fine of ₹20,000 per child employed. National & State Commissions for Protection of Child Rights & Children’s Courts – estb in 2005 Act, for speedy trial of offences. Child Labour (Prohibition & Regulation) Act, 1986 was amended in 2016, renamed as Child & Adolescent Labour (Prohibition & Regulation) Act, 1986- Prohibits employment of children below 14 years for any occupation. Prohibits employment of adolescents (14-18 yrs) in certain hazardous occupations. Imprisonment of 6 months to 2 yrs, or fine of ₹20000 to ₹50000 or both. Repeated offences – imprisonment for 1 to 3 years. Right to Freedom of Religion. Article 25-28. Art 25 – Freedom of Conscience & free profession, practice & propagation of religion. Art 26 – Freedom to manage Religious Affairs. Art 27 – Freedom from Payment of taxes for promotion of any religion. Art 28 – Freedom from attending religious instruction or worship in certain educational institutions. Freedom of Conscience & Free Profession, Practice & Propagation of Religion. Art 25 – equal rights to citizens & non-citizens. Freedom of Conscience : inner freedom of person to mould religious mindset. Freedom to profess : Open & free declaration of faith & religious beliefs. Right to Practice : performing rituals, ceremonies, worshipping, etc. Right to propagate : preaching & promoting religious belief (except by force). Exceptions : Subject to public order, health, morality, Fundamental rights. State can restrict economic, financial, political activity associated with religious practice. State can provide for social welfare & reform or throw open Hindu Religious institutions of public character to all classes & sections of Hindus. Art 25 contains 2 explanations : Carrying of Kripans is included in profession of Sikh religion/’Hindus’ in this context include Sikhs, jains, Buddhists. Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs. Art 26 – All religious denominations & their sects will have following rights : Right to estb or maintain inst. for religious or charitable purposes. Right to manage it own religious affairs. Right to own & acquire movable & immovable property. Right to administer such owned property in accordance with law. Art 25 give Individuals’ rights, Art 26 gives rights to religious org as whole. Subject to public order, morality, health. SC held 3 conditions for recognition as religious denomination : Should be a collection of individuals with system of beliefs conducive to their spiritual wellbeing. Should have a common organisation. Should be designated by a distinctive name. Accordingly SC held ‘Ramakrishna Mission’ & ‘Ananda Marga’ as religious denomination of Hindu religion. Freedom from Taxation for Promotion of Religion Art 27 – No person shall be compelled to pay tax for promotion of religion. State cannot use public money to promote or maintain any one religion, however state can promote or maintain All religions. It does not prohibit collection of fees only of taxes. Freedom from Attending Religious Instruction Art 28 – no religious instruction in educational Institutions maintained by State funds. Does not apply on inst. admin by State but estb under endowment or trust, requiring imparting of religious instruction. Person cannot be forced to attend religious instruction in State inst. Art 28 gives 4 edu inst. – (a) Institutions wholly maintained by State/(b) Institute admin by the State/(c) Inst recognised by the State/(d) Inst receiving State aid. In (a) religious instruction prohibited/ in (b) religious instruction permitted /in (c) & (d) religious instruction permitted on a voluntary basis. Cultural & Educational Rights Article 29-30. Art 29 – Protection of language, script & culture of minorities. Art 30 – Rights of Minorities to establish & administer educational institutions. Protection of Interests of Minorities. Art 29 – any section of citizen has the right to preserve their own distinct language, script or culture. No citizen will be denied admission into Edu inst, partly or wholly maintained by the State, on the basis of their religion, caste, race or lang. Grants protection to both religious & linguistic minorities. SC held that this Right also applies to majority. SC also held that Right to conserve land also includes Right to to agitate for the protection of language, therefore, political speeches promising the same will not amount to corrupt practice under Representation of the People Act, 1951. Right of minorities to estb & admin Edu Inst. Art 30 – grants following rights to religious & linguistic minorities. Right to estb & admin Edu Inst of their choice. The compensation amount fixed for acquisition of minority Edu inst property by the State shall not violate their Right. (44th Amd, 1978). State cannot discriminate against minority inst in granting aid. ‘minority’ term is not defined in the Constitution. Right also includes right to impart education to children in own lang. Minority Edu Inst are of 3 types : Inst that seek recog & aid from State (Subject to regulation by State). Inst that seek only recognition. (Subject to regulation by State). Inst thag neither seek aid nor recognition from State (only subject to general law). The Supreme Court has held : The right of minorities to estb & admin Edu Inst includes : Right to choose its governing body/to appoint teaching & non-teaching staff/to admit eligible students of their choice & set reasonable fees/to use its assets for benefit of the institution. Art 30 is only to ensure equality & not estb dominance over majority, so general laws of the land apply on all. Art 30 is not absolute, therefore State can set regulations to prevent maladministration, to maintain education standards, welfare of students & staff, to prevent Exploitation, to set syllabus & curriculum of study. Such regulations does not interfere with Art 30. Subject to regulations being met, unaided minority inst will have right to appoint teaching & non-teaching staff. Extention of aid does by State does not alter the nature & character of the minority Edu inst. Right to Constitutional Remedies. Article 32 – Right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights including the writs of Habeas Corpus. Mandamus. Prohibition. Certiorari. Quo warranto. SC held Art 32 as Basic Structure of Constitution. Ambedkar declared this Article to be the most important Art of the Constitution. Constitutional Provisions. Right to move SC by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. SC will have power to issue directions or orders or writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Parliament can empower any Court (apart from HC which are already empowered by Art 226) with similar powers without reducing powers of SC. Right under Art 32 to move courts can be suspended during National Emergency (Art 359). Only Fundamental Rights can be enforced through Art 32. Both Supreme Court & High Court have original jurisdiction in cases related to violation of Fundamental Rights. Writs. Writs are written orders issued by court to protect Fundamental Rights. SC (Art 32) & HC (Art 226) can issue writs. Borrowed from British Constitution. SC can issue writs only to enforce Fund Rts, but HC can issue writs for legal rights as well. SC can issue writs to person or Govt in entire territory of India, HC can issue writs to persons or Govt inside their respective State or UT territories or to persons or Govt outside if cause of action arises within their respective state or UT territory. SC under Art 32 (being a Fundamental Right) is bound to issue writs in cases of violation of Fund Rts. HC under Art 226 has discretionary power & may refuse to issue writs. Types of Writs. Five writs are available to both SC & HC (& any Court empowered by Parl.) : Habeas Corpus : “ to have the body of” . Order issued to any person who has detained another person to bring the body of the latter before the court to determine its legality. Can be issued against public authorities & private Individuals. Not issued when : detention is lawful/proceeding is for contempt of leg or court/detention is by competent court/detention is outside territory. Mandamus : “we command”. Issued to a public official asking to perform his duty which he may have failed or refused to do. Also issued to any public body, Corp, inferior Court, tribunal or Govt. Cannot be issued : to enforce departmental instruction which doesn’t have statutory force/against private indv or body/when duty is discretionary/to enforce contract/against Prez or Gov or CJ of HC. Prohibition : “ to forbid ” . Issued by higher court to lower court or tribunal to prevent the later from exceeding its jurisdiction. Certiorari : “ to be certified or informed ”. Issued to lower court or tribunal to transfer a case to issuing authority or to quash the order of the Court or tribunal, on grounds of excess or lack of jurisdiction or error of law – also available agn admin authority. Both Preventive & Curative in nature. Quo warranto : “ by what authority or warrant ”. Issued to enquire into legality of claim of a person to a public office. Only in case of substantive public office of permanent character created by a statute or the Constitution. Can be sought by any interested person not necessarily aggrieved. Criticism & Significance. Criticisms of Fundamental Rights. Excessive Limitations : Subjected innumerable exceptions, restrictions, qualifications & explanations. No Social & Economic Rights : Mainly consists Political Rights. Social Rights like Right to Social Security, work, employment, rest & leisure, etc are not comprehensive, unlike other advanced Democratic Constitutions. No Clarity : Vaguely defined – terms like ‘public order’, ‘minorities’, reasonable restrictions, ‘public interest’ not defined. Complicated lang used. No Permanency : Not sacrosanct. Can be abolished. ‘Doctrine of Basic Structure’ is only protection of Fundamental Rights. Suspension during Emergency : Suspension of Fundamental Rights during Emergency is against Democratic values & is autocratic. Expensive Remedy : Judicial Process for appeal is very expensive. Preventive Detention : Hampers spirit of Fundamental Rights. Gives arbitrary powers to the State by making Prev Detention Constitutional. Significance of Fundamental Rights. Bedrock of Democratic system in India. Provides material & moral protection to human beings. Formidable bulwark of individual liberty. Establish Rule of Law in the country. Protect minorities & weaker sections. Strengthen Secular fabric of Indian State. Check the absoluteness of the authority of the Govt. Foundation of Social equality & social justice. Ensure dignity & respect of individuals. Facilitate participation of people in political & administrative process. Rights outside of Part-lll. Rights outside of Part-lll are known as Constitutional or Legal Rights : Article 256 in Part-Xll — No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law. Article 300-A in Part-Xll — No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law. Article 301 in Part-Xlll — Trade, commerce & intercourse throughout the Territory of India shall be free. Article 326 in Part XV — The elections to the Lok Sabha & the State Legislative Assemblies shall be on the basis of Adult Suffrage. All Legal Rights are equally justiciable to Fundamental Rights. No Right to Constitutional Remedies available. SC cannot be directly approached, HC can be moved under Art 226 or Ordinary suit.

Introduction. Citizens are full members of the Indian State. Aliens are citizens of other States which are foreign : Enemy Aliens – from enemy countries, with no protection against arrest and detention. Friendly Aliens – from friendly countries with certain rights. Constitution deals with Citizenship in Part-ll — Art 5 to 11. Constitution does not elaborate on acquisition or loss of citizenship. Elaborated later by Parliament in Citizenship Act, 1955. Only identifies persons who became Citizens on 26 Jan, 1950 : (a) persons domiciled in India / (b) persons migrated from Pakistan / (c) persons migrated to Pakistan but later returned / (d) persons of Indian origin residing outside India. Constitutional Provisions. Constitution confers the following Rights & privileges on Indian Citizens : Right against discrimination (Art 15) / Right to Equality (Art 16) / Right to Freedom (Art 19) / Cultural & Educational Rights (Art 29-30) / Right to Vote for Lok Sabha & Leg Assemblies / Right to contest elections for Parliament & State Leg / Eligibility to hold certain high Offices like President, VP, SC & HC judge, Governor, AG. Art 9 – Person loses citizenship if he/she acquires foreign citizenship. Art 10 – Parliament has power to restrict citizenship by law. Art 11 – Parliament given all powers for matters of acquisition & termination of citizenship and all other matters. Citizenship Act, 1955. Provides for acquisition & loss of Citizenship after 26 Jan, 1950. Act has been amended by the Parliament in 1958, 1960, 1985, 1986, 1992, 2003, 2005 & 2015. Originally also provided for Commonwealth Citizenship, but this was repealed in 2003. Acquisition of Citizenship. Citizenship Act, 1955 provides for 5 ways to Acquire Citizenship : By Birth (born inside India) : Person born after 26 Jan, 1950 & before 1 July 1987 are Citizens irrespective of Parent’s nationality— after 1 July, 1987 must have one Indian parent at birth. Person born after 3 Dec, 2003 must have one Indian parent while the other parent must also not be an illegal immigrant. Children of Foreign Diplomats & Enemy Aliens are not citizens. By Descent (born outside India) : Person born on or after 26 Jan, 1950 & before 10 Dec, 1992 must have father as citizen—after 10 Dec, 1992 any parent must be citizen. From 3 Dec, 2004 person born outside must also be registered at Indian consulate within 1 year of Birth, after 1 year with permission of Central Govt. Minor citizen with other foreign citizenship must renounce all foreign citizenships within 6 months of turning 18. By Registration (on application, not being an illegal immigrant) : Person of Indian origin residing in India for 7 years before applying. Person of Indian origin residing outside undivided India. Person married to citizen & resident for 7 years. Minor children of citizens of India. Adult person whose parents are ‘registered citizens’ of India. Adult— who herself or either parent are former citizens — after residing for 12 months immediately before application. Adult registered as Overseas Citizen of India cardholder for 5 years —immediately after residing 12 months. Person of Indian origin is with either parent born in undivided India or in other territories acquired after Independence. All of the above persons must take an oath of allegiance. By Naturalisation (on application, not being an illegal immigrant) : Following qualifications : Should not a subject or citizen of a country which does not allow Indians to gain citizenship of that country through naturalisation. Must give an undertaking to renounce foreign citizenship. Has either resided in India for or has worked for Govt (or partly done both) for 12 months immediately before application — must have also resided or served Govt for a minimum aggregate of 11 years in a span of 14 years before the said 12 months of immediate residence. Must be good of character. Must have adequate knowledge of any lang in 8th Schedule. Must intend to reside in India, or enter or continue Govt service or service in international org of which India is a member or under an org estb in India. Govt may waive all above conditions for distinguished service. Must take an oath of allegiance. By Incorporation of Territory : Govt specifies citizens of a newly occupied foreign territory through an executive order – Citizenship (Pondicherry) Order, 1962. Special Provisions for Citizenship of Persons covered by Assam Accord : Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 1985 laid following special provisions : Persons of Indian Origin who came to Assam before 1 Jan, 1966 from Bangladesh and have been ordinarily residents of Assam since are citizens. Persons of Indian Origin who came to Assam after 1 Jan 1966 but before 25 March 1971 from Bangladesh and have been ordinarily residents of Assam since & has been detected to be a foreigner, shall register himself. The person shall not be a Citizen for a period of 10 years from the date of detection as a foreigner, but shall have all rights and obligations as an ordinary citizen except the Right to Vote. Loss of Citizenship. By Renunciation : Any citizen can register a declaration of renunciation with the Central Govt. During war, registration can be withheld by Govt. Upon renunciation, minor child also loses citizenship (can voluntarily resume citizenship after attaining the age of 18). By Termination : Citizenship is automatically terminated when a person voluntarily acquires foreign citizenship (not applicable in times of war). By Deprivation : Compulsory termination of Citizenship by Central Govt. If citizenship had been obtained by fraud. Disloyalty to the Constitution of India. Unlawful trade or communication with enemy during war. Two years imprisonment in any country, within 5 years of registration or naturalisation of the citizen. Ordinarily resident of a foreign country for 7 years, unless citizen is a student or Govt servant or has registered annually to retain citizenship. Single Citizenship. India provides for a National Citizenship only (no citizenship of States). Citizens of India are equal in all States without discrimination, however there are certain exceptions as follows : Art 16 allows Parliament to prescribe residence as a condition for certain employments & appointments in states & UTs. Art 15 does not prohibit discrimination on the basis of residence so States can offer special benefits like educational fee concessions. Art 19 (Freedom of Movement & Residence) is curtailed in relation to scheduled Tribal areas — outsider residence is restricted. J&K Legislature has powers to define ‘permanent residents’, confer special rights and privileges in Govt employment, acquiring immovable property, settlement in state, scholarships, etc. Overseas Citizenship of India. Non-resident Indian : Any Indian citizen residing in foreign country. Person of Indian origin (PIO) : Who, or whose ancestors, were citizens. Overseas Citizen of India Cardholder : Sep 2000 – Committee on Indian Diaspora under L. M. Singhvi setup. 2003 Amendment Act – created OCI for PIO of 16 countries which allow dual citizenship (extended to all in 2005) except Pakistan & Bangladesh. 2015 – renamed as OCI Cardholder by merging PIO & OCI card scheme. Eligibility – same conditions as for Citizenship except residency. Benefits – can visit India life long without visit (however special permission required for research work) / almost same treatment as NRIs (except in matter relating to agricultural or plantation properties). Non-entitlement : Right to Equality of Opportunity in public employment / election for President & VP/Appointment as SC or HC judge & to specific public services / Right to vote/ contest elections.

Introduction. Part l — Article 1 to 4. Article 1 describes ‘India, that is, Bharat’ as a “Union of States”. To establish the Quasi-Federal Structure. According to Article 1- the Territory of India includes : 1. Territories of the States. 2. Union Territories. 3. Territories that may be acquired by the Govt of India. Union of States. Names of States & Union Territories & their extents – Schedule 1. 29 States & 7 Union Territories. Const. prov. for States apply to all States equally (except J&K). States share a distribution of power with Centre (Subject Lists). Union Territories & acquired territories are Centrally admin. India can acquire foreign territory by International Law : By Cession – after treaty, purchase, gift, lease or plebiscite. By Occupation – if unoccupied by any recognised ruler. By Conquest or Subjugation. Art 2 empowers Parliament to admit or establish new States which are not a part of Union of India. Admitting foreign States like Sikkim. Converting Union Territories. Reorganisation of States. Art 3 authorises Parliament to : Form a new State by Seperation of territory from any State; by uniting two or more States or part of States; or by uniting any territory to a part of State. Increase the area of a State. Diminish the area of any State. Alter the boundaries of any State. Alter the name of any State. 18th Amendment, 1966 added power to form a new State or UT but uniting a part of any State or UT to any other State or UT. Art 3 can be used only with the prior recommendation of the President, who before making recommendation, must refer the Bill to concerned State Legislatures for their views within specified time. President is not bound by the concerned State’s views. President doesn’t have to refer to State Legislature after every amendment to the original Bill. Art 4 declares that laws made Article 2 & 3 are not Constitutional Amendments under Article 368. These Bills can be passed like Ordinary Bills (Simple Majority). SC in 1960 held that Indian Territory can only be ceded to a Foreign State by Constitutional Amendment through Art 368. SC in 1969 held that Settlement of Boundary Dispute does not require amendment, only executive action. 100th Const. Amend. Act, 2015 in pursuance of Land Boundary Agreement between India and Bangladesh, 1974. Under this, India transferred 111 ‘enclaves’ to Bangladesh in return for 51 enclaves from them/Demarcated 6.1 km border strech. For this territories of 4 states were modified in First Schedule. Integration of Princely States. The Indian Independence Act of 1947 gave Princely States freedom to choose to join India, to join Pakistan or remain indep. Of 552 total Princely States, 549 joined India, 3 refused. Hyderabad was integrated by means of Police action. Junagarh by referendum. Kashmir by Instrument of Accession.
